headline: 24 Years Later, DNA Leads to Arrest in Manhattan Attack on a Girl
text: It was one of those ugly, unsolved crimes that seem to haunt many neighborhoods in New York City: In February 1993, a man with a knife abducted an 11-year-old girl in an apartment building hallway in the Hamilton Heights section of Manhattan, forced her to the roof and sexually assaulted her.

headline: Libraries Are Fining Children Who Can’t Afford to Be Without Books
text: Library fines are the first serious penalties that most children run into outside the home, and for generations, they have been education and vexation.

headline: The Reality of a Pre-Existing Condition
text: PARIS — I read the news about the passage of the House health care bill a continent away, on assignment in Europe. The distance did nothing to lift the weight on my heart, as the parent of a child with a pre-existing condition.

headline: In France, a Stark Debate and a Stark Choice
text: It was the most brutal French presidential debate anyone could remember, two and a half hours of interruptions, insults, sarcasm and invective between the 48-year-old, far-right populist Marine Le Pen and the 39-year-old, centrist upstart Emmanuel Macron. They called each other liars, arrogant, dangerous and many other things, often paying little heed to the two moderators.

headline: Starlin Castro, a Star Without Patience, Can’t Wait for Wrigley Return
text: CHICAGO — Starlin Castro was fed up as the 2013 season came to a close, and not just because of another last-place finish for the Chicago Cubs, their fourth in a row. No longer was he a beacon of a brighter future. After making the National League All-Star team the previous two seasons — all by the time he had turned 23 — Castro was lost, his head swimming with other people’s ideas about the type of player he should be.

headline: Sessions Closed Sterling Case. Odds Are, His Predecessor Would Have, Too.
text: WASHINGTON — To Jeff Sessions’s biggest critics, his decision this week not to charge two white police officers in the shooting death of a black man in Louisiana was the realization of their fears of an attorney general who promised a pro-police stance on civil rights matters.

headline: The ‘Superstore’ Season 2 Finale: A Disaster (on Purpose)
text: Disruption can sometimes be turned into opportunity, and Thursday night’s clamorous Season 2 finale of “Superstore” proved it. The show, a well-written NBC comedy full of exceedingly likable characters, is set in a Walmart-like retail outlet, and by the episode’s end, the store was in ruins, having been leveled by a tornado.

headline: Fox News Besieged by New Bias Lawsuit and Federal Inquiry
text: New troubles for Fox News arose on Thursday as a lawsuit accused it of gender discrimination and one of the women who have accused Bill O’Reilly of sexual harassment said she would appear before the British regulatory group that is assessing 21st Century Fox’s attempted takeover of Sky, the satellite TV giant.

headline: He’s a Real Contender to Lead Congo, if Only He Could Get In
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Moïse Katumbi, the opposition leader in the Democratic Republic of Congo, has everything a presidential candidate needs: money, a strong record in government, nationwide recognition and, to top it all off, a wildly popular soccer club.

headline: Private Hearing With Intelligence Chiefs Revives House Inquiry on Russia
text: WASHINGTON — The House’s investigation into Russian meddling in the election lurched back to life on Thursday, as a closed-door hearing with James B. Comey, director of the F.B.I., and Adm. Michael S. Rogers, head of the National Security Agency, cleared the way for the inquiry to move forward.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Health Care Bill, Passed by House, Faces Senate Test
text: “You have every provision of this bill tattooed on your forehead. You will glow in the dark.”

headline: In Rare Unity, Hospitals, Doctors and Insurers Criticize Health Bill
text: It is a rare unifying moment. Hospitals, doctors, health insurers and some consumer groups, with few exceptions, are speaking with one voice and urging significant changes to the Republican health care legislation that passed the House on Thursday.

headline: Review: ‘The Ferryman’ in Jez Butterworth’s Northern Ireland
text: LONDON — It’s a mighty full house that’s presided over by Quinn Carney, the divided Irish hero of Jez Butterworth’s “The Ferryman,” which burst open at the Royal Court Theater here on Wednesday night, where its run is already sold out. (It moves to the West End in June.) The fiercely gripping play in which Quinn, a father of seven, appears is every bit as crowded.

headline: Message of Puerto Rico Debt Crisis: Easy Bets Sometimes Lose
text: When some of Wall Street’s savviest hedge funds piled into Puerto Rico’s debt in 2014, it seemed like an easy bet: Buy up the island’s bonds at a discount, pocket the high interest and persuade politicians to make decisions that would raise the value of their investments.

text: Iran responded angrily on Thursday to criticisms by Saudi Arabia’s defense minister, accusing him of acts that violate the United Nations Charter and calling his kingdom an instigator of “dangerous ambitions in the region and beyond.”

A year ago, few predicted that the French presidential race would boil down to a matchup between Marine Le Pen, a far-right candidate from a party with a racist, anti-Semitic legacy, and an upstart former banker who had never held elective office, Emmanuel Macron. But here we are.

headline: Dust Storms Blanket Beijing and Northern China
text: HONG KONG — Dust storms enveloped parts of northern China for a second day on Friday, reducing visibility in cities like Beijing and threatening the health of millions of people.

headline: Shaming Children Over School Lunch Bills
text: The humiliation inflicted on children whose parents are late paying school lunch bills — or are too poor to pay them at all — is a national disgrace. Cafeteria workers berate the children for being unable to pay, rather than allowing them to eat, or stigmatize them by stamping their arms with messages like “I need lunch money.” An article in The Times on Monday recounted the painful experience of one student whose meal was dumped in the garbage.

headline: How Democrats Can Win in the West
text: HELENA, MONT. — I AM no fan of Neil Gorsuch or his legal theories, but his appointment to the Supreme Court raises a question that Democrats must answer. Justice Gorsuch is the first person from the Mountain States named to the court since Ronald Reagan chose Sandra Day O’Connor from Arizona in 1981. Since then, Democratic presidents have appointed four justices, all more or less drawn from the Washington-New York-Harvard-Yale corridor. Why was it left to President Trump to finally take a person from the American West or, for that matter, anywhere from the interior of the country?

headline: No Country for This Old Man
text: In his three calamitous months in office, President Trump has visited a property that is part of his business empire nearly once every three days. And while Barack Obama had gone to nine countries in that amount of time, Trump has been to no other nation — though he just announced an overseas trip for later this month.

headline: Clergy Members Aren’t Being Persecuted for Their Politics
text: Even in the long, inglorious history of trumped-up causes, the idea that American clergy members are persecuted by the government for speaking their minds takes the cake.

headline: What’s the Matter With Europe?
text: On Sunday France will hold its presidential runoff. Most observers expect Emmanuel Macron, a centrist, to defeat Marine Le Pen, the white nationalist — please, let’s stop dignifying this stuff by calling it “populism.” And I’m pretty sure that Times rules allow me to state directly that I very much hope the conventional wisdom is right. A Le Pen victory would be a disaster for Europe and the world.

headline: Mexican Drug Smugglers to Trump: Thanks!
text: NOGALES, Mexico — Crouched in the spiky terrain near this border city, a veteran smuggler known as Flaco points to the steel border fence and describes how he has taken drugs and people into the United States for more than three decades. His smuggling techniques include everything from throwing drugs over in gigantic catapults to hiding them in the engine cars of freight trains to making side tunnels off the cross-border sewage system.

headline: When Countries Think They Can Go D.I.Y.

Here are a few more places that pursued the D.I.Y. approach to illogical conclusions.

headline: Rebuilding the New York Aquarium After Hurricane Sandy
text: Jon Forrest Dohlin has been at the New York Aquarium for so long that when he walks past the Sea Cliffs display, he greets the harbor seals by name. They pop their heads up and silently greet him back. But Mr. Dohlin knows more than just their names. He also knows what their new home will look like.

headline: A Romance Novel Within a Novel Steals the Show
text: THE ROMANCE READER’S GUIDE TO LIFE By Sharon Pywell 308 pp. Flatiron Books. $25.99.

headline: G.O.P. Cheers a Big Victory. But Has It Stirred a ‘Hornet’s Nest’?
text: WASHINGTON — No one knows better than House Democrats how a contentious health care vote can exact a steep political price — losing control of the House in the first midterm election of an untested new president’s tenure for example.

headline: Growing Up in, and Outgrowing, Manhattan
text: When asked whether he considers New York City to be his home, my father responds with, “No, I am a man of the world.” His affected response is probably that of many a prototypical Manhattanite. For him and others like him, this slender island between the Hudson and East Rivers is a conduit to something much more.

headline: So Chris Rock Is Your Big Brother? Try Comedy
text: LOS ANGELES — From a distance, he looked familiar. The same brash confidence. The fierce energy. And there was something about his measured gait as he walked on the dimly lit stage at Los Globos, a club in Silver Lake, that made you go, “Hey, I know him.”

headline: The Broken Promises of Choice in New York City Schools
text: It was a warm Sunday morning, the breeze sweeping aside the last wisps of summer, and 31 students from Pelham Gardens Middle School in the Bronx had signed up to spend the day indoors, at a showcase for New York City’s public high schools.

headline: Friday Mailbag: A Columnist Has a Fiery Debut and Another Goes Missing
text: Last Friday, Bret Stephens announced his arrival at The New York Times with a debut column on climate change. Our inbox, as the public editor noted in her Wednesday column, was inundated: Over a thousand letters have streamed in and counting.

headline: Second Chance for ‘Obamacare’ Repeal. And for Reince Priebus.
text: WASHINGTON — The Republican health care overhaul might never become law, but it has already changed the life of one American: Reince Priebus, who knew it was his best and perhaps last hope of becoming an empowered White House chief of staff.

headline: Oysters, Despite What You’ve Heard, Are Always in Season
text: There’s no “r” in May — much to the dismay of oyster lovers who’ve learned to follow this rule of thumb: Eat raw oysters only in months containing the letter “r.”

headline: How Four Powerful Rulers Decided the Fate of a Continent
text: FOUR PRINCES Henry VIII, Francis I, Charles V, Suleiman the Magnificent and the Obsessions That Forged Modern Europe By John Julius Norwich 288 pp. Atlantic Monthly Press. $27.

headline: Jobless Rate at 10-Year Low as Hiring Grows and Wages Rise
text: The jobless rate dropped to 4.4 percent in April, the lowest level in more than a decade, the government said on Friday, signaling the economy’s resilience and showing a labor market closing in on full capacity.

headline: Teenagers in The Times: April 2017
text: Welcome to the April 2017 edition of Teenagers in The Times, our monthly roundup of the news and feature stories about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com. You can find our next installment on June 2.

headline: Late Night Is Unimpressed With the House’s Health Care Bill
text: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

headline: Teaching With: ‘The Forger’
text: In times of war and persecution, having the right passport can mean the difference between life and death. The 16-minute documentary film “The Forger” tells the story of Adolfo Kaminsky, who as just a teenager during World War II helped save the lives of thousands of Jews by forging passports so they could escape the Nazis.

headline: What Democrats’ Losses in 2010 Can Tell Us About G.O.P.’s Chances in 2018
text: There’s no way to know how the health care debate in Congress will play out, but there’s a lot of reason to think that the House vote to replace the Affordable Care Act has put Republicans on a risky path heading into next year’s midterm elections.

headline: Republican Party, Uber, Kentucky Derby: Your Friday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Abstention, France’s Last Temptation
text: PARIS — According to the most recent polls, Emmanuel Macron, leader of the En Marche! movement, will become the next president of France: He is forecast to win 61 percent of votes in the second, and final, round of the election on Sunday, against 39 percent for Marine Le Pen, of the far-right National Front. The die appears to be cast — at least according to numerous pollsters, and their reputation was recently burnished by the accuracy of their predictions for the first round on April 23.

headline: In Panama, a Restaurant as Remote as It Is Satisfying
text: Panga, on the Azuero Peninsula of Panama, is over 60 miles from the nearest supermarket. “It’s like I live on a boat,” said Andrés Morataya, the restaurant’s chef. Yet what Panga lacks is what has helped define it.

headline: Tending My Daughter’s Crown
text: She was rushing past me into the bathroom, a whir of caramel skin and blue jeans and reddish-brown locs flying behind her, when I noticed the patch of uneven Afro stretching across at least a third of the back of her head.

text: Adele White and Hussain Gilani grew up with a lot of faith. Ms. White, a native of Frankfort, Ky., started a Baptist prayer club in junior high school. Under her leadership, the group grew so large that it met in the gymnasium.

text: This interview with Freeman A. Hrabowski III, president of the University of Maryland, Baltimore County, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: The Death and Life of Jersey City
text: Between Jersey City’s downtown and waterfront districts sits a single-story windowless pillbox of a bar with a sign outside that says “Golden Cicada.”

headline: U.N. Rights Expert, on Visit to Philippines, Denounces ‘War on Drugs’ Approach
text: MANILA — Implicitly rebuking the leader of the Philippines on a visit to his country, the United Nations’ top expert on extrajudicial killings said on Friday that governments around the world had rejected the “war on drugs” approach being championed by President Rodrigo Duterte.

headline: North Korea Accuses South and U.S. of Plotting to Kill Kim Jong-un
text: SEOUL, South Korea — In a region already tense over nuclear threats, North Korea accused the South Korean and American intelligence agencies on Friday of plotting to assassinate its leader, Kim Jong-un, and it warned of an unspecified counterattack.

headline: Cartoonists Earn a Prime Minister’s Ire — and His Subscription
text: SOFIA, Bulgaria — A cartoon in the latest issue of Prass Press, a new satirical newspaper in Bulgaria, depicts leaders “in charge of the global circus”: President Trump straddling a missile; Kim Jong-un of North Korea preparing to launch a warhead with a slingshot; and the prime ministers of Bulgaria and Hungary under the label “baby dictators.”

headline: Is a Sub-Cultural Revolution Threatening Hong Kong?
text: HONG KONG — Fifty years ago this weekend broke out what arguably remains the most violent and most traumatic incident in the city’s history since World War II. On May 6, 1967, a labor dispute at a factory producing plastic flowers in the district of Kowloon triggered an eight-month crisis that killed 51 people and injured 832, and momentarily brought the Cultural Revolution to Hong Kong.

headline: California Today: Democrats See a Launching Pad in Trump
text: Good morning.

headline: Decoding the Trump-Turnbull Handshake
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Donald Trump’s handshakes with world leaders are often revealing moments. So what can be gleaned from the grip-and-grin between Mr. Trump and Australia’s prime minister, Malcolm Turnbull?

text: We’re following major developments in the markets throughout the day. Check below for the latest updates.

headline: Justin Trudeau and the Case of the ‘Star Wars’ Socks

headline: Take It From a 93-Year-Old Yogi: Stretch, Hold and Laugh
text: “Its not a basement; it’s a sanctum sanctorum,” said Ronnie Arond, 93, as a half-dozen yoga students convened in the basement of her modest house in Bellerose, Queens.

headline: Long Island City Grows Ever Skyward
text: Justin Elghanayan stood on a roof, gazing at a forest of half-built towers. “For a long time this neighborhood was about what will be,” said Mr. Elghanayan, the president of Rockrose Development, “and now I think it’s about what is.”

headline: ‘Angels in America,’ Still Stretching Toward the Heavens
text: LONDON — And so the great work has begun once again.

headline: Navy SEAL Killed in Somalia in First U.S. Combat Death There Since 1993
text: WASHINGTON — A member of the Navy SEALs was killed and two other American service members were wounded in a raid in Somalia on Friday, the first American combat fatality there since the 1993 “Black Hawk Down” battle.

headline: Edward Snowden and Cory Doctorow Talk Sci-Fi and Reality
text: About half an hour into Cory Doctorow’s discussion of his new science-fiction novel, “Walkaway,” at the New York Public Library on Wednesday, the man interviewing him suddenly froze in midsentence.

headline: U.K. Conservatives Gain and Labour Stumbles in Harbinger of General Election
text: LONDON — In voting for local councils on Thursday, just five weeks before the British general election, the governing Conservative Party made significant gains, the opposition Labour Party did badly and the centrist Liberal Democrats had mixed success.

headline: The Art Market Is Still Waiting for an Online Revolution
text: LONDON — E-commerce is revolutionizing the world of retail. Online sales in the United States have grown by an average of $40 billion a year over the past three years, posing an existential threat to brick-and-mortar shopping. This year, Amazon is set to overtake Macy’s, which plans to close 100 stores, as America’s biggest apparel seller.

headline: Bresha Meadows, an Ohio Teenager Accused of Killing Father, Seeks Release Before Trial
text: Bresha Meadows was 14 when she took her father’s gun and shot him last July, putting an end to what some relatives say were years of abuse visited upon her, her mother and her siblings.

headline: Wizards vs. Celtics: Pushing, Shoving, and Occasional Basketball
text: WASHINGTON — Even as they clutter their games with pushes and shoves, with scuffles and kerfuffles, the Washington Wizards and the Boston Celtics share common ground.

headline: 2017 Kentucky Derby Contenders: The Experts Make Their Picks
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — The horses for the 143rd running of the Kentucky Derby are listed in order of post position, with comments by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. The morning-line odds were set by Mike Battaglia of Churchill Downs.

headline: E.U. Leader Says (in English) That English Is Waning
text: BRUSSELS — Jean-Claude Juncker couldn’t resist a little dig, and it drew a big laugh.

headline: A Season of Regret for an Aging Tribal Expert in India
text: NEW DELHI — At 82, the anthropologist T. N. Pandit passes his days in the gentle occupations of old age: poetry, a Buddhist study circle, a daily walk in the park. It is rare for anyone to ask him about the years he spent with the hunter-gatherer tribes of the Andaman Islands. Only with difficulty can he locate a single copy of the slender book he wrote about that time.

headline: We’re Getting Awfully Close to Full Employment
text: There is one prism through which we should analyze the April jobs numbers released Friday and each of the remaining reports in 2017: How close to full employment are we, really?

headline: Regulator in China Takes Aim at Anbang Insurance Group
text: SHANGHAI — A Chinese regulator announced on Friday that it had taken disciplinary measures against the Anbang Insurance Group, a financial behemoth that has tried to invest tens of billions of dollars overseas, for the improper sale of two investment products.

headline: Women Who Have the Chops (and the Punches and the Kicks)
text: Speeding car chases, heart-stopping hand-to-hand combat, bodies left for dead on the pavement, a backdrop of international espionage. The director David Leitch’s latest film has all the elements of a Jason Bourne or James Bond blockbuster — except for one major difference. It’s a woman throwing the punches.

headline: Chris Kraus and Jill Soloway Talk About the Show ‘I Love Dick’
text: Twenty years ago, “I Love Dick” — Chris Kraus’s novel chronicling her one-sided obsession with a cultural critic named Dick and how she staked out her own identity as a writer through a wild series of letters to him — was published to little notice. Since then, it has grown into a feminist cult classic. The book anticipated an era of popular female autofiction — from Emily Gould’s “And the Heart Says Whatever” to Sheila Heti’s “How Should a Person Be?” — and with a cheeky title that feels made to be Instagrammed, it has taken on new resonance as a text for women in the social media age. This month, it will continue its pop cultural rise with a television adaptation by another feminist auteur.

headline: A Taiwanese Classic Now Available in English
text: NOTES OF A CROCODILE By Qiu Miaojin Translated by Bonnie Huie 304 pp. New York Review Books. $15.95.

headline: On the French Election
text: On Sunday France will hold its presidential runoff.

headline: Jay Cutler Joins Fox as an N.F.L. Analyst
text: Jay Cutler, cut by the Chicago Bears after eight years as their starting quarterback, will leave the game to become an analyst on Fox.

headline: The Hunted
text: In parts of southern Africa, people with albinism are killed or sold by traffickers.

headline: Russia Says Deal Bars American Jets From Much of Syria’s Skies. U.S. Says No.
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — United States and allied aircraft will be banned from flying over much of Syria as part of a deal struck by Iran, Russia and Turkey to foster a cease-fire in the Syrian war, a senior Russian diplomat said Friday.

headline: A Story Collection Tracks Nepal’s Highs and Somewhat Lows
text: MAD COUNTRY Stories By Samrat Upadhyay 294 pp. Soho Press. Paper, $16.

headline: An Auschwitz Magician’s Greatest Trick: Holding the Horrors at Bay
text: “All right, pick a card,” Werner Reich said, fanning out a worn deck of cards in his Long Island home to demonstrate a trick he’d learned in an unlikely place: on the top of a bare wooden bunk in the concentration camp barracks at Auschwitz.

headline: On the Mountain Top With a French Presidential Candidate
text: PAU, FRANCE — Not surprisingly it’s very different to travel with a French presidential candidate than with an American one. Granted, this was not an ordinary trip for Emmanuel Macron, the centrist candidate for president of France, but still. We (myself and the French photographer, Pierre Terdjman) took a flight at dawn down to Pau, which is inland from Biarritz and in the plains just below where the Pyrenees begin. There we joined with a press pool following Mr. Macron.

headline: Classic Mediterranean Flavors, Enlivened by Ramps
text: In the Mediterranean pantry, olive oil reigns. Black and green olives in varying hues and sizes abound. Capers, the pickled flower buds of a wild vine, are a constant, too, at the ready with their briny, floral scent. Most cooks in the region use anchovies, preserved in salt or oil, in their daily cooking, in whole fillets, chopped or pounded in a mortar. Wild thyme, rosemary and oregano are the herbs of choice, and garlic is a given.

headline: For Some, Britain Proved a Port in the Storm of War
text: LAST HOPE ISLAND Britain, Occupied Europe, and the Brotherhood That Helped Turn the Tide of War By Lynne Olson Illustrated. 553 pp. Random House. $30.

headline: How Dr. Eric Kandel, Neuroscientist, Spends His Sundays
text: Forget that he’s 87.  Eric R. Kandel, who specializes in the biology of memory and is a professor in the neuroscience and psychiatry departments at Columbia University, works more than he ever has before, he said. Dr. Kandel, who won a Nobel Prize in 2000, continues to write books and is co-director of the Mortimer B. Zuckerman Mind Brain Behavior Institute at Columbia and a senior investigator at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute in Chevy Chase, Md. He lives with his wife of 60 years,  Denise Kandel, 84, an epidemiology professor at Columbia, in Harlem.

headline: Sharing an Apartment With Strangers
text: Over the last decade, Long Island City, Queens, has become a refuge for Manhattan professionals who want a short commute and an apartment in an amenity-laden high-rise, but don’t want to split a Murray Hill two-bedroom three ways to get it.

headline: Rikers Deemed Too Dangerous for Transferred Inmates
text: The jail complex on Rikers Island has failed to comply with minimum safety standards and has become so dangerous, according to a New York State oversight agency, that it can no longer be permitted to accept inmate transfers from outside New York City.

headline: A Kaleidoscopic John Giorno Retrospective, Sprinkled Around New York
text: Since the 1960s, John Giorno has been a nexus of New York’s downtown art scene. This 80-year-old poet, artist and activist had been a muse of Andy Warhol’s and has hosted dinner parties with friends like Patti Smith, Robert Mapplethorpe and Keith Haring. In more recent years, he has collaborated with the French artist Pierre Huyghe and starred in the music video for R.E.M.’s final single.

headline: There’s No Escape From Contamination Above the Toxic Sea
text: BORNE By Jeff VanderMeer 323 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $26.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: House Republicans Move to Gut Bank Regulations
text: WASHINGTON — Republicans took a big step toward repealing the Affordable Care Act on Thursday, and they took a small step toward dismantling another of President Barack Obama’s signature pieces of legislation, the Dodd-Frank Act.

headline: Custom Stalls and Air-Ride Suspension: How Derby Horses Travel in Style
text: Like Nyquist, American Pharoah and California Chrome, the horse that wins Saturday’s Kentucky Derby will be covered in a blanket of roses. And — whether or not it appreciates it — that horse will bask in the adulation of the finely turned-out spectators at Churchill Downs.

headline: Poor Credit History Can Affect Homeowner’s Insurance Rates
text: The impact of one’s credit history on homeowner insurance rates appears to be intensifying, a new analysis shows.

headline: The Five Lies Hollywood Tells Itself
text: We’re heading into blockbuster season, long designed to part young men with their money using male heroics, computerized wizardry and the requisite side babes. But in a sign that slow-to-react movie studios are betting there’s lucre in catering to a wider array of audiences — something television has known for a while — the summer of 2017 is bringing alternates to tried and tired formulas, with the likes of “Wonder Woman,” starring Gal Gadot; “Atomic Blonde,” with Charlize Theron; and the Tupac Shakur biopic, “All Eyez on Me,” with Demetrius Shipp Jr. in the lead.

headline: The Latest in Crime Fiction
text: It’s hard to get good help these days. That’s the complaint of the stressed-out Glaswegian gangsters in EVERY NIGHT I DREAM OF HELL (Mulholland/Little, Brown, $26), a piece of writing that lives up to its gritty title. It’s especially difficult to find disciplined professionals like Nate Colgan, an enforcer for the Jamieson gang and the reliable chronicler of Malcolm Mackay’s novel. Although he’s skilled at handling the dirty jobs, Nate is no meathead. “Times had changed,” he explains. “Big organizations had become more sophisticated and the standard of muscle had gone up.”

headline: Chicago’s South Side Golf Courses in Line for a Tiger Woods Upgrade
text: CHICAGO — Gus Sims, 67, has heard what might happen to his beloved, no-frills public golf course on Chicago’s South Side, where, on a balmy spring morning here, he was setting out to play a leisurely nine holes.

headline: In a Law Office, Coping With a Boss’s Toxic Trail
text: My first full-time job was in an estate planning law firm in Midtown Manhattan, working as a paralegal. It was 1992, I was 22 and, having just graduated from college with a double major in English and philosophy, I was ill qualified for just about everything in the nonacademic world. Nothing in my undergrad curriculum helped me write wills or powers of attorneys, or most important, as it turned out, make coffee for Mr. S.

headline: Roasted Asparagus and Scallion Salad
text: Roasting asparagus and scallion together deepens their flavor, and when paired with whole grains soaked in a garlicky citrus vinaigrette, it all comes together in a salad bursting with umami.

headline: A Bold Take on Asparagus, Deep in Its Season
text: The first few weeks of asparagus season are a frenzied time in our house.

headline: At the Movies: Our Monsters, Ourselves
text: Summer is fast approaching, and so too is a cavalcade of creeping, slithering, stomping monsters. The nifty independent “Colossal,” which features a Godzilla-like creature terrorizing Seoul, South Korea, is still in theaters. “Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2” and its science-fiction bestiary opened on Friday, May 5. The latest “Alien” movie is drooling in the wings, and “The Mummy” lands in June. The next “Planet of the Apes” flick arrives in July, and while that franchise may not feature traditional fiends, it finds the monstrous in a familiar place: human beings. Our chief film critics, Manohla Dargis and A. O. Scott, discuss monsters and wonder how they could be any more frightening than real life.

headline: Senate Asks Trump Associates for Records of Communication With Russians
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate Intelligence Committee has asked a number of high-profile Trump campaign associates to hand over emails and other records of dealings with Russians as part of its investigation into Russian meddling in the presidential election and is prepared to subpoena those who refuse to cooperate, officials said.

headline: Actors Share How They Got the Job
text: Sometimes the hardest part isn’t what happens on the set — it’s landing the role in the first place. Here, a handful of actors gracing the screen this summer talk about how they got a crucial job.

headline: A Sample Executive Email Carpet Bomb
text: A letter from Ron Lieber, the Times’s Your Money columnist, to executives at Jewel-Osco about a dangerous condition at a grocery store that was affecting neighbors (including his mother).

headline: Republicans Disregarded the C.B.O., but It Won’t Be Ignored
text: Now that the House has passed its big health care bill, it will find out what that bill could actually do.

headline: In Rare Move, Death Sentence in Delhi Gang Rape Case Is Upheld
text: NEW DELHI — India’s Supreme Court upheld on Friday the death sentence for four men who were found guilty of raping and disemboweling a 23-year-old student on a moving bus in 2012, a crime that came to embody the menace lurking in India’s sprawling, chaotic cities.

headline: 10 Things to Do in NYC Now
text: This exhibition takes a first shot at the long-overlooked history of ’80s American painting and mostly misses its mark. The heady, poly-style energy of the moment is intermittently present, often in works — previously long in storage — by Julian Schnabel, Kathe Burkhart, Moira Dryer and several others. But the show, which closes on May 14 and is limited to the museum’s collection and its smallest floor of galleries, is confused and timid. Still, don’t miss it. So far, it’s all we have. ROBERTA SMITH

headline: Danny DeVito and Christopher Lloyd, Back to the ’70s
text: Danny DeVito, whose performance as an antiques dealer in Arthur Miller’s “The Price” received a Tony Award nomination for best featured actor this week, said he learned to make the most out of smaller roles long ago, in 1974, during auditions for the film version of “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest.” Actors were called back again and again to improvise in character, as psychiatric patients. Mr. DeVito, who had been in a play version of “Cuckoo’s Nest,” had to make up his own dialogue while honing facial expressions, body language, even speech patterns.

headline: Gabourey Sidibe Talks About ‘This Is Just My Face’
text: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

headline: At Afghanistan-Pakistan Border, Forces Clash and at Least 11 Die
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — At least 11 people were killed and dozens were wounded on Friday in clashes between Afghan and Pakistani forces on the border between the two countries, officials said.

headline: Farmer’s Market Shopping With the Chef Tom Colicchio
text: Before the celebrity chef Tom Colicchio set me straight, I didn’t know that ramps grow only in the wild. These garlicky leeks can’t be raised in captivity, but must be foraged in rich, moist forests.

headline: Is the Met Opera Too Big? And Other Questions as Its Home Turns 50
text: When an opera company moves into a new home, there’s always lingering nostalgia for the old one. But fans of the Metropolitan Opera were more than ready to vacate the worn old Met at 39th Street and Broadway for a massive new theater at Lincoln Center. The old Met, I vaguely remember from attending a few performances as a teenager, had fine acoustics and, with its golden horseshoe interior, a kind of faded, dusty grandeur. But backstage resources were woefully inadequate.

headline: Triumph, Tragedy and 50,000 Hats: The Met Opera by the Numbers
text: When the Metropolitan Opera moved to Lincoln Center from Broadway at 39th Street in 1966, a subway token cost 20 cents, the Supremes’s “You Can’t Hurry Love” was at the top of the Billboard charts, and the (pre-miracle) Mets were wrapping up their fifth season. Since then, a lot of sopranos have gone on to meet tragic but beautiful-sounding ends. As the Met prepares to celebrate its 50th anniversary at Lincoln Center with an all-star gala on Sunday, May 7, here is a look at its first half-century in its new home — by the numbers.

headline: ‘The Handmaid’s Tale’ Episode 4 Recap: Survival Lessons
text: Memory can be a weapon or a wound, it’s all a matter of perspective. As Offred struggles with nearly two weeks of imprisonment in her room, her memories soon appear to be both. Her memories of the time she, Luke and Hannah went to a carnival prove to be a potent refuge. But Offred tries not to linger in the past, worried it will only compound her fragile mental state. It’s too easy to get lost remembering the way things were rather than grappling with the present.

headline: Ellsworth Kelly’s Studio, Just as He Left It
text: Jack Shear lived with Ellsworth Kelly for 32 years, in a house adjacent to the studio where Mr. Kelly worked, in Spencertown, N.Y. After Mr. Kelly’s death in 2015, Mr. Shear preserved the studio intact, occasionally photographing the space, until Mr. Kelly’s last canvases were removed to be shown at the Matthew Marks Gallery in New York. I spoke to Mr. Shear about the images he made and his time with the artist.

headline: Checking for the Latest Windows 10 Update
text: Q. How do I know if my computer updated itself to the new Creators version of Windows 10 that just came out? I looked in the system information box and it doesn’t tell me anything that mentions “Creators Update.” And are there any problems to expect with this version of Windows 10?

headline: You Twist. You Turn. You Move. (And You’re Just the Viewer.)
text: Making art, for the filmmaker and choreographer Lily Baldwin, comes with responsibility. “Can I make you feel something?” she said. “Can I turn you on?”

headline: Caitlyn Jenner’s Stolen Red Shoes and Other Revelations
text: When somebody steps into the tabloid glare as willingly and relentlessly as Caitlyn Jenner has, a memoir might seem greedy, or at least redundant. What can be left to overshare? Still, here comes a Jenner memoir with the tattletale title “The Secrets of My Life” (written with Buzz Bissinger and new at No. 8 in hardcover nonfiction), and it turns out to be plenty revealing. Jenner discusses her ambivalence at becoming a macho role model after winning decathlon gold as Bruce Jenner, along with her early experiences cross-dressing and her attempts to reconcile her gender identity in a succession of doomed marriages. She also relates a funny anecdote about appearing on a Bob Hope television special after the Olympics, for a skit that required dressing in drag. “I have to be careful not to show too much enthusiasm, so I play it cool," she remembers. “Our wigs and dresses are purposely ridiculous. But the red heels I think not only look good on me but also fit, so I steal them after the show.”

headline: In Case You Missed It: April's Top Real Estate Stories
text: Catch up on the most popular stories of the month.

headline: LeFrak Goes Upscale With Its Latest Tower in Jersey City
text: Standing on a muddy pile of concrete and brick at the edge of a construction site in Jersey City, the developer Richard LeFrak glanced up at the 41-story glass and steel tower rising on the bank of the Hudson River. “Somebody once asked me, ‘What’s the best part of the business?’ This is the best part,” he said, referring to the thrill of building a new tower.

headline: The Senate Intelligence Committee Letter
text: Lawmakers investigating Russian election meddling wrote to a number of high-profile Trump campaign associates over the past 10 days, asking them to hand over records of communications and dealings with Russian officials and business people.

headline: Singing ‘Happy 450th Birthday’ to Monteverdi
text: It seems logical and simple enough: a performance of Monteverdi’s 1610 Vespers on Tuesday, the composer’s 450th birthday. Logical, yes; simple, not entirely.

headline: From the London Whale to Wells Fargo, a Bank Regulator Looks Back
text: Thomas J. Curry’s first week as a federal banking regulator was his worst.

headline: At $495, Lonzo Ball’s ZO2 Sneakers Have Tastemakers Saying No Thanks
text: At the Flight Club sneaker store just south of Union Square on Thursday night, eager customers perused the gleaming shelves, hunting for classic kicks. The big names — the players whose signature shoes are most highly sought — are the ones you would expect: Kevin Durant, LeBron James and, even after all these years, Michael Jordan.

headline: Trump Jokes Are at a Record Level on Late Night
text: In December, Stephen Colbert told CBS’s John Dickerson in an interview, “Now I have no choice but to actually enjoy this incredible gift every day that Mr. Trump will be,” referring to the oft-repeated notion that President Trump would be a boon to late-night comedy shows.

headline: Daily Report: Uber Stays in the Spotlight
text: Uber, the world’s dominant ride-hailing service, has gone barely a week this year without making headlines. This week has been no exception.

headline: Children and Homework

text: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this Playlist? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com, and sign up for our Louder newsletter here.

headline: A Fatal and Fiery Photograph Reawakens Memories of a Soldier’s Life
text: In the days after Specialist Hilda Clayton was killed during a training exercise in Afghanistan, an online condolence book sprang up on a website hosted by The Augusta Chronicle, her hometown newspaper in Georgia. Friends and family shared memories of her human rights essay in school, her love of football, and the way she said “Mom and Dad I’m home” when she walked through the door.

headline: Ivanka Trump, White House Adviser-in-Training
text: To the Editor:

headline: The House Just Passed Its Version of a Health Care Bill. What’s Next?

headline: White House Proposes Cutting Drug Control Office Funding by 95%
text: WASHINGTON — When he was running for office, Donald J. Trump promised to rid America of the scourge of drugs, vowing to crack down on dealers and invest heavily in programs to get heroin and other opioids off the streets.

headline: Worry in Scorched Fort McMurray: How Many Will Walk Away?
text: FORT McMURRAY, Alberta — When a group of Fort McMurray homeowners gathered Wednesday evening for a block party, they had beer, rye whisky and soft drinks. What they didn’t have was much of a block.

headline: Finding Feist’s Pleasure and Pain
text: The Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times. It covers the latest in pop music criticism, trends and news.

headline: Michelle Obama Tweets Phone Number of Former White House Staff Member
text: Any White House employee would likely appreciate a public shout-out from the former first lady, but this probably wasn’t what Duncan Wolfe had in mind.

headline: Some Things T Editors Are Really Into Right Now
text: On the spring/summer 2017 runways, a handful of models had dark-rimmed eyes so smudged that the phrase “next-day makeup” didn’t do the look justice. The new Chanel makeup artist Cyndle Komarovski calls it an “updated version of a smoky eye,” and adds that in order to achieve the look at home, “all you need are your fingertips.” As for why you would want to — we’re taking a cue from the shows, where the rebellious eye makeup added a nice edge to the season’s more delicate and feminine designs. Below, Komarovski walks us through the steps.

headline: Minnesota Sees Largest Outbreak of Measles in Almost 30 Years
text: Health officials are grappling with the largest outbreak of measles in Minnesota in almost 30 years, which is mainly sickening young children of Somali immigrants who fell under the sway of anti-vaccination activists.

headline: Skeptical Junior and Proud G.O.P. Dad Discuss Health Care
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cuttlefish Battle
text: A cuttlefish conflict escalated from a visual display of aggression into actual aggression in the first recording of a physical battle between male cuttlefish.

headline: A Rare Opportunity to Scream at the Company’s Owner
text: As a representative of irate consumers across the country, the Haggler often toils on behalf of people who want nothing more than to find executives and scream in their faces. But that opportunity is rare. Corporate leaders are usually insulated by underlings, which makes their faces difficult to find.

headline: Battle of Cuttlefish Caught on Tape
text: Cuttlefish, relatives of octopus and squid, have millions of color cells in their skin, which gives them extraordinary control over their appearance. They are brilliant at camouflage, and they can also create displays to communicate to other cuttlefish.

headline: Should Free Markets Govern the Bond Rating Agencies?
text: There’s a lot not to like in the Financial Choice Act, the deregulatory construct put forward by House Republicans on April 28. Dubbed by its creators the “alternative to the failed Dodd-Frank Act,” it aims to repeal the 2010 law’s prohibition against banks engaging in risky trading for their own accounts. It also seeks to gut the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, one of the more effective agencies in Washington.

headline: Sterling Jewelers Settles Charges of Bias Against Female Workers
text: Sterling Jewelers has settled federal civil charges accusing it of discriminating against female employees, reaching a deal without having to admit wrongdoing or pay any damages, a win for the company as it faces continuing legal challenges over its pay and promotion practices.

headline: Review: ‘Ski End’ Recalls Fun on the Slopes With Nostalgia
text: After finding themselves locked in an abandoned Vermont ski store, a group of friends has the only reasonable reaction: “I guess we live here now,” one says.

headline: White House Fires Its Chief Usher
text: WASHINGTON — The chief usher at the White House, Angella Reid, who was the second African-American and the first woman to have a job whose title belies its broad responsibilities, was fired this week, administration officials said.

headline: Macron Supporters Woo Undecided French Voters
text: Even though Emmanuel Macron is leading in the polls ahead of France’s presidential election on May 7, his supporters are leading a grass-roots effort to prevent voters from abstaining or backing Marine Le Pen, the far-right candidate.

headline: April’s Most Popular Listings
text: All of the most visited listings on The New York Times’s “Find a Home” site last month were in Brooklyn and Manhattan. Our list includes a $50 million penthouse in a Zaha Hadid-designed building, two Brooklyn houses, a financial district loft and an apartment in the East Village.

headline: The Necessary Empire
text: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia — Elections in the Netherlands, France and Germany this year have brought much drama to the old Carolingian core, where Charlemagne founded his empire in the ninth century. This has always been the richest and most strongly institutionalized part of Europe. But should the European Union continue to weaken, the most profound repercussions will be felt farther east and south.

headline: 12 Great Stories That Have Nothing to Do With Politics
text: Welcome to Our Picks, a guide to the best stuff to read, watch and listen to from around the internet. Check this space for the must-read long-form article, the next great podcast for your commute, the news-making tweetstorm. And yes, we’re also tooting our own horn here. We’ll share can’t-miss Times articles from the week and reveal some gems you might have overlooked.

headline: Review: Is ‘Los Elementos’ Opera? That’s Beside the Point
text: As the reconstituted New York City Opera continues to test its sea legs with a second presentation in its series Ópera en Español, it would be nitpicky and pointless to insist on calling this latest installment “Ópera (o Algo Parecido) en Español.” But strictly speaking, “Los Elementos,” by the 18th-century Spanish master Antonio de Literes (which follows the Mexican composer Daniel Catán’s “Florencia en el Amazonas” of last June), is only “something like” an opera.

headline: Spring Awakening
text: Benefits were held last week for the Bronx Children’s Museum, Planned Parenthood, Lincoln Center and Pioneer Works.

headline: Spring Awakening
text: The spring gala season is in full bloom. Planned Parenthood held its 100th anniversary gala on May 2 at Pier 36. The Bronx Children’s Museum held its inaugural gala on May 2 at Tribeca Rooftop. Lincoln Center held its spring gala on May 2 at Alice Tully Hall. And Pioneer Works held its fourth annual Village Fete on April 30 at its home in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

headline: Flooding in New York Shuts Down Roads and Strands Drivers
text: Over the course of just a few hours on Friday, a heavy downpour sent floodwaters through the streets, shutting down roads, stranding motorists, and causing delays on transit systems throughout the New York region.

headline: Are These Birds Too Sexy to Survive?
text: In a mossy forest in the western Andes of Ecuador, a small, cocoa-brown bird with a red crown sings from a slim perch. Bip-Bip-WANNGG! It sounds like feedback from an elfin electric guitar. Three rival birds call back in rapid response. These male club-winged manakins are showing off to attract female mates.

headline: The Story Was Fine, the Headline Less So
text: When the House of Representatives passed the Republican health care bill Thursday, The New York Times was quick to publish a sidebar that mapped out the bill’s potential impact on individuals. The winners? The wealthy and upper middle class. The losers? The poor and elderly.

headline: What the Republican Health Plan Gets Right
text: Now that the Obamacare replacement bill has passed the House and is moving on to the more centrist Senate, the real debate begins. What is the true purpose of health insurance, and what is our government’s goal in ensuring we have it?

headline: Florida University to Award Posthumous Degree to Trayvon Martin
text: Trayvon Martin, the Florida teenager whose shooting death by a neighborhood watch volunteer in 2012 prompted a national debate over racial profiling and civil rights, will be awarded a posthumous university degree in aeronautical science that reflects the 17-year-old’s dream of becoming a pilot before he was killed.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What We’re reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

headline: Shopping for Outdoor Furniture
text: Choosing outdoor furniture isn’t easy. You need something that combines comfort, low maintenance and not just good looks, but the right kind of good looks.

headline: Summer Movie Release Schedule 2017
text: All dates are subject to change.

headline: Daniel Loeb’s Pitch for Honeywell May Go Too Far
text: Daniel S. Loeb may be spinning his Honeywell International story a bit too far. The activist investor behind the hedge fund Third Point wants the $100 billion conglomerate to spin off its aerospace unit. That could be an option, but Mr. Loeb’s pitch that it would increase shareholder value by $20 billion is a stretch.

headline: Younger Men, Older Women: A Pairing Becomes More Common
text: The lead-up to the French presidential election has been rife with debates over immigration, terrorism and the European Union, but one nonpolitical factor has fascinated the public in France and abroad: the 24-year age gap between Emmanuel Macron, 39, the candidate who will face off against Marine Le Pen on Sunday, and his wife Brigitte, 64.

headline: The ‘Best’ Places to Move in Retirement? They’re All Over the Map
text: What’s the best place to live in retirement?

headline: Demi Moore’s Central Park Penthouse Sells for $45 Million
text: The actress Demi Moore finally closed on her triplex penthouse atop the south tower of the landmark San Remo. It took two years to reach a deal, and a $30 million reduction from the original asking price, which had included a two-bedroom maisonette.

headline: Why Even a Live-Tweeting Senator Couldn’t Stop a Deportation
text: For nearly nine hours on Wednesday, it seemed as though a tweetstorm might be enough to stop a deportation.

headline: Debra Winger Comes to Terms With Fame and Age
text: The gaggle of diners glanced up from their table at Locanda Verde in TriBeCa, their eyes out on stalks as they took in the lithe figure heading their way.

headline: After ‘Brexit’ and Trump, Trust Is an Issue With French Polls
text: The mood in France is “tense.” Europe is on “tenterhooks.” The world is “on edge.”

headline: Critiquing the House’s Health Bill
text: To the Editor:

headline: The U.S. Case vs. El Chapo: 10,000 Pages and Recordings
text: It has been assumed for months that the prosecution of Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the Mexican drug lord known as El Chapo, would be an undertaking of major proportions.

headline: Trump’s 2nd Nominee for Army Secretary Withdraws
text: WASHINGTON — Mark E. Green, President Trump’s second nominee to be secretary of the Army, withdrew from consideration on Friday, saying in a statement that his nomination had become a distraction because of “false and misleading attacks against me.”

headline: Greg Gianforte on Health Care
text: The Montana candidate talked about the bill to repeal and replace Obamacare.

headline: Daliah Lavi, Actress in Both Dramas and Spoofs, Dies at 74
text: Daliah Lavi, an Israeli actress who transitioned from serious parts in foreign cinema and in dramatic films like “Lord Jim” to lighthearted turns in 1960s spy-movie spoofs like “Casino Royale,” died on Wednesday at her home in Asheville, N.C. She was 74.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
text: This week’s properties are in Fairfield, Conn., and Garden City, N. Y.

headline: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and New York
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in the New York region:

headline: The Fabulous Apple Cash Machine
text: Great things are expected of the most valuable company on the planet.

headline: ‘The Wrong Kind of Hot’
text: Meryl Streep reads from an essay by Sheila Nevins.

headline: For the Couples in This Alexei Ratmansky Ballet, Love Is Not Enough
text: When the choreographer Merce Cunningham was asked in 1991 what his vivid new piece, “Neighbors,” was about, he replied, “Three neighborhood couples, probably from the suburbs.” To the next question, “Is that all?,” he answered, “Isn’t that enough?” Alexei Ratmansky could say much the same about “Odessa,” his peculiar and marvelous new creation for New York City Ballet, except that his characters aren’t suburban: They’re outgoing, intense, sophisticated up to a point, but thoroughly provincial.

headline: Mexico’s President Vows to Step Up Protections for Journalists
text: MEXICO CITY — Faced with a wave of deadly attacks against journalists, the president of Mexico has vowed to take concrete steps to ensure the safety of journalists in his country, including removing the lead prosecutor responsible for investigating crimes against the freedom of expression.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: This week’s properties are in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, the Upper West Side and Harlem.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York City:

headline: To Lift Growth, Janet Yellen Says, Make It Easier for Women to Work
text: In an unusually personal speech, Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said Friday that policies making it easier for women to work could significantly improve the nation’s economic growth.

headline: What to Cook, Watch, Listen To and More This Weekend
text: 47 times a day.

headline: Second Dewey & LeBoeuf Jury May Be Bracing for a Long Deliberation
text: Jury deliberations in the retrial of two former Dewey & LeBoeuf executives on criminal charges arising from the law firm’s collapse are starting to have a familiar ring.

headline: France’s Presidential Election Splinters the Country’s Culturati
text: PARIS — The French comedian Sophia Aram took to the airwaves of one of France’s most popular morning radio shows this week. In the squealy voice of a teenage girl, she cried, “I can be against toothbrushes, and against cavities!” She then added: “Hashtag: NeitherCheeseNorDessert.”

headline: Being an ‘Old Lady’ Role Model in Hollywood? Not Easy
text: LOS ANGELES — My first encounter with Sheila Nevins, the president of HBO Documentary Films, was in 2011 at the Sundance Film Festival. Her greeting involved an unprintable rant about thin motel walls and oversexed festivalgoers. I won’t lie: It knocked the wind out of me.

headline: Open Thread: This Week in Style News
text: Each week, the Open Thread newsletter will offer a look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. The latest newsletter appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Abortion Foes See Ally in Trump, but Wonder: Will He Go Far Enough?
text: WASHINGTON — There are few constituencies as pleased with President Trump’s three and a half months in the White House as the anti-abortion groups that rallied to his side during the 2016 campaign.

headline: In Conversation With Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie
text: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, a feminist icon and mainstay in conversations about women’s equality, did not originally intend for her newly released book, “Dear Ijeawele; Or, A Feminist Manifesto in Fifteen Suggestions,” to be published. It started first as a private letter to a friend who sought Ms. Adichie’s advice on how to raise her newborn daughter “so she doesn’t take the kind of nonsense that I took,” before being published on her Facebook page and now, finally, in print.

headline: Moonlit Handel: This Week’s 8 Best Classical Music Moments
text: In addition to reviews, features and news during the week, our critics and reporters collect the best of what they’ve heard: notes that sent shivers down their spines, memorable voices, quotations that cut to the heart of the story.

headline: 5 Books to Read on Kentucky Derby Day
text: To get a handle on which horse to bet among the 20 entrants in tomorrow’s Kentucky Derby, turn to The Times’s Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert. While they were busy handicapping the field, I was turning, as I usually do at this time of year, to my fairly robust shelf of books about the sport. Assuming you’re already familiar with Laura Hillenbrand’s best-selling “Seabiscuit” (and if not, then with its film adaptation), here are a handful of other books to read on Derby Day, and during the rest of the Triple Crown season that follows it.

headline: G.O.P. House Candidate in Montana Is Caught on Tape Praising Health Bill
text: WASHINGTON — When Greg Gianforte, the Republican running for an open House seat in Montana, was asked on Thursday whether he would have supported the bill repealing the Affordable Care Act that passed the House that day, he declined to answer.

headline: A Rural Shrine to New York’s Angels and Gargoyles
text: CHARLOTTEVILLE, N.Y. — New York City has nearly 750 museums and galleries that showcase paintings, dinosaurs, ships, fire trucks and gangsters, to name a few. But when it comes to a certain category of lost New York, the most intriguing collection is in a museum 175 miles away: stone fragments that once adorned city buildings.

headline: A U.S. Hiring Plan Falls Short of Reform
text: Infosys, the giant Indian company that supplies American businesses with foreign technology workers, has announced that it will hire 10,000 Americans in the United States in the next two years. This might seem like an early victory in President Trump’s “Hire American” campaign, but it’s less of a cause for celebration than it appears.

headline: Republican Party, Emmanuel Macron: Your Friday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Yankees Defeat Cubs on Ninth-Inning Home Run by Brett Gardner
text: CHICAGO — Starlin Castro had played enough games at Wrigley Field that he did not need to be at the stadium on Friday to know which way the wind would be blowing.

headline: The Color of Protest
text: On Thursday evening, protesters in New York signaled their resistance to President Trump by standing outside the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum, awaiting his first homecoming since taking office, with many wearing white in honor of the suffragist movement. Meanwhile, another form of dissent in a different shade was underway downtown.

headline: Leaving College, Going to War
text: Much as the Blue Ridge Mountains towered over campus, “Vietnam” loomed constantly in the background that spring, exactly 50 years ago, when 264 classmates and I were preparing to graduate from the all-male, almost all-white Washington & Lee University in Lexington, Va. Next door at the Virginia Military Institute, where the graduates would automatically become commissioned officers, Vietnam loomed even larger.

headline: Willing to Cook for Strangers, but Guests Are Harder to Find
text: In a penthouse apartment in Manhattan’s Chinatown on a recent Monday night, Lisa Larsson chopped shiitake mushrooms and looked rather relaxed for someone about to host a 14-person dinner.

headline: F.C.C. Will Review Complaints About Colbert Joke, Chairman Says
text: Ajit Pai, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said in a radio interview that his agency was reviewing complaints about a controversial joke told by Stephen Colbert, the CBS late-night host, to determine if further action was warranted.

headline: Canada Today: A Fire’s Lingering Effects, Novelty Socks and a Secretive Tax Program
text: Each week, Canada Today mixes The Times’s recent Canada-related coverage with back stories and analysis from our reporters, along with opinions from our readers.

headline: Locked Up for Being Poor
text: Maranda Lynn ODonnell, a 22-year-old single mother in Harris County, Tex., was arrested last year for driving without a valid license. The judge set her bail at $2,500. She couldn’t afford anything close to that, so she spent three days in jail — even though she posed no risk of skipping town or endangering anyone if she were released.

headline: Police Officer Who Fatally Shot 15-Year-Old Texas Boy Is Charged With Murder
text: BALCH SPRINGS, Tex. — A police officer in a Dallas suburb was charged with murder on Friday, six days after he fired his rifle into a car full of teenagers leaving a party, killing a black 15-year-old in the front passenger seat.

headline: Macron Campaign Says It Was Target of ‘Massive’ Hacking Attack
text: PARIS — On the eve of the most consequential French presidential election in decades, the staff of the centrist candidate Emmanuel Macron said late Friday that the campaign had been targeted by a “massive and coordinated” hacking operation, one with the potential to destabilize the nation’s democracy before voters go to the polls on Sunday.

headline: First, It’s Baby Steps for American Pharoah’s Progeny
text: LEXINGTON, Ky. — A feeling of hope rippled across bluegrass country, and everywhere else in the world of racing, when at 12:30 a.m. on Jan. 3 a mare named Kakadu gave birth to the very first foal by the Triple Crown winner American Pharoah.

headline: Rape Charges to Be Dropped in Case Cited by White House as Immigration Issue
text: Prosecutors in Maryland said on Friday that they would drop rape charges against an undocumented immigrant and another high school student, adding a new twist to a case that the White House had held up as evidence of the need to be tough on illegal immigration.

headline: To Understand Macron’s Economic Vision, Look to France’s ‘Last Chance’ Students
text: BOBIGNY, France — When Emmanuel Macron rolled out his presidential campaign nearly six months ago, he came to a little-known vocational school in Bobigny, a working-class suburb of Paris. The backdrop was chosen to burnish his image as the candidate who would revive France, especially for young people.

headline: I Have No Idea Who Will Win the Kentucky Derby
text: Not long ago I was invited to compile a volume for the Library of America dedicated to the history of horse racing in this country, a sport and a pastime that was well underway before the Declaration of Independence. When I began, I thought it might be helpful to commit to memory the winners of the Kentucky Derby, beginning with Aristides — the speedball chestnut trained by a former slave named Ansel Williamson who bested the legendary racehorse Ten Broeck and 13 other colts in 1875 — and going all the way up to last year’s champion, Nyquist, named for a Swedish hockey star.

headline: Adolph Kiefer, a Gold Medal Backstroker in the 1936 Olympics, Dies at 98
text: Adolph Kiefer, a celebrated swimming champion who won gold as a teenager at the 1936 Berlin Olympics and might well have become one of America’s greatest Olympic champions if World War II had not intervened, died on Friday at his home in Wadsworth, Ill. He was 98.

headline: Justice Department Expands Its Inquiry Into Uber’s Greyball Tool
text: SAN FRANCISCO — An inquiry by the United States Department of Justice into Uber’s use of a program to deceive some regulators has expanded.

headline: Red Sox, Racism and Adam Jones
text: When I heard that the Baltimore Orioles outfielder Adam Jones was showered with racial epithets by fans at Fenway Park on Monday, it was easy for me to roll my eyes and say, “Of course — Boston.”

headline: Corrections: May 6, 2017
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: The Met Files a Formal Proposal to Charge Admission to Out-of-State Visitors
text: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has moved one step closer to mandatory admission fees: It filed a formal proposal with the city this week to charge admission to out-of-state visitors, a lawyer revealed in a court hearing on Friday, a controversial idea given that the Met is in part supported by tax dollars and currently has only a “suggested” entrance fee.

headline: A Second Drug Is Approved to Treat A.L.S.
text: A new drug for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrig’s disease, was approved on Friday by the Food and Drug Administration.

headline: Penguins Carry Signs (and Posters and Rugs) of Home on the Road
text: WASHINGTON — It’s springtime, and the Penguins are nesting.

headline: Judge in Puerto Rico’s Debt Lawsuit Handled Major Financial Cases
text: As a federal court judge, Laura Taylor Swain has played a role in two of the highest-profile financial criminal cases of the past decade. Now she will preside over one of the biggest local government financial failure cases ever filed.

headline: Fact Check: Rumors, Claims and Context on G.O.P. Health Bill
text: WASHINGTON — Rumors that the Republican health care bill counts rape, domestic violence and ulcers as uninsurable pre-existing conditions are circulating among opponents of the bill. But these claims are overly simplistic.

headline: Vote to Kill Retirement Account Rule Draws Criticism From State-Level Republicans
text: WASHINGTON — An idea to make it easier for Americans to save for retirement that was introduced at the conservative Heritage Foundation is in the cross hairs of a conservative Republican Congress.

headline: Paintings by A.R. Penck
text: A.R. Penck, a Neo-Expressionist, painted in East Germany and exhibited in the West under aliases until he was expelled by the government in 1980.

headline: A.R. Penck, German Neo-Expressionist of Cold-War Era, Dies at 77
text: A. R. Penck, a leader in the German Neo-Expressionist movement of the 1970s and ’80s, which brought a new sense of historical and political drama to figurative painting, died on Tuesday in Zurich. He was 77.

headline: Chelsea Bombing Suspect Wants Hospital Interviews Suppressed
text: Ten days after a bomb exploded in Manhattan’s Chelsea neighborhood in September, injuring more than 30 people, investigators arrived at a hospital surgical intensive care unit in New Jersey to question a man charged in the attack, Ahmad Khan Rahimi.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Senate Panel Asks Trump Associates for Communications With Russians
text: “I am eager, indeed anxious, to testify in full public session, have requested no immunity and am ready to go.”

headline: Ivanka Trump Promotes Her Book on Social Media (but Not in the Media)
text: Ivanka Trump will continue to promote her new book on Twitter and Instagram, according to a spokeswoman, weeks after President Trump’s adviser and daughter pledged not to draw publicity through a promotional tour or media appearances.

headline: Mixed Signals From Trump Worry Pro-Israel Hard-Liners
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump hosted Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, at the White House this week with all the usual bonhomie he displays for foreign leaders. Within hours, he wrote on Twitter that it had been “an honor,” adding, “Hopefully something terrific” would come out “between the Palestinians & Israel.”

headline: Puerto Rico: A Debt Problem That Kept Boiling Over
text: It all goes back to 1917.

headline: Measure on Pre-existing Conditions Energizes Opposition to Health Bill
text: From the moment the Republican-controlled House of Representatives approved a plan to overhaul the health care system, an onslaught of opposition to the bill has been focused on a single, compact term: pre-existing conditions.

headline: Illustrated Books by Peter Spier
text: Peter Spier was a prolific children’s book author and illustrator.

headline: Peter Spier, Illustrator of Children’s Books, Dies at 89
text: Peter Spier, an award-winning children’s-book author and illustrator who depicted Noah’s biblical journey, told the story of the Erie Canal to the words of the song “Low Bridge, Everybody Down” and gave voice to the sounds of hundreds of animals like hippos (“RRUMMPF) and starlings (“FEE-YOU”), died on April 27 in Port Jefferson, N.Y. He was 89.

headline: Where’s Ivanka When We Need Her?
text: Ivanka’s got a new female empowerment book, and Dad’s going to war against women. Great week, gang.

headline: Travis d’Arnaud Joins Many Other Mets on the Disabled List
text: Because of rainy conditions, the Mets did not even play a full game on Thursday in Atlanta, yet they still arrived at Citi Field on Friday with more injury news.

headline: What Has Failed in France
text: Americans live to work, while the French work to live. That’s the cliché, and it’s time to retire it. If Emmanuel Macron defeats Marine Le Pen in Sunday’s election — let’s pray the polls are right this time — the message from voters will be: The vacation in Martinique will have to wait. First, we’d like to work.

headline: 18 Penn State Students Charged in Fraternity Death
text: WASHINGTON — Eighteen students at Penn State University were charged Friday in the death of a 19-year-old sophomore who became drunk and fell repeatedly during a fraternity “pledge night” in February. Authorities said the student was left overnight, unconscious and obviously injured, by fraternity members who knew he needed help but failed to seek it.

headline: Center of a Blowout
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — In yesterday’s column, I recommended trusting your brain to fill in the gaps between letters in your crossword. The same thing applies today, except that it’s a bit harder because today is a day later and Saturday puzzles are that much harder.

headline: E.P.A. Chief Recuses Himself From Suits Opposing Obama-Era Rules
text: WASHINGTON — Scott Pruitt, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, has removed himself from some of the most contentious cases facing it, including challenges to the Obama administration’s Clean Power Plan and a controversial rule related to the Clean Water Act.

headline: Boxing Struggles, but It Has a Culture in Its Corner
text: Thirty-four years ago, the boxing promoter Bob Arum was having lunch at the Friars Club with Carlos Barba, the manager of a Newark-based Spanish-language television station that would eventually become the broadcasting giant Univision.

headline: Ivanka Trump’s Collectible Quotations
text: You might think, spending enough time on Instagram or Pinterest, that Susan Sontag’s primary contribution to the world was a line of inspirational postcards.

headline: Mets Turn to Small Ball to Edge the Marlins
text: The Mets’ principles for constructing a contender are steadfast and clear. Games are won by batters who can send pitches over the outfield walls and by powerful starters who can employ devastating fastballs to overwhelm opposing hitters.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘The Graduate’ and the Kentucky Derby
text: “The Graduate” celebrates an anniversary year. Classic Empire runs the course at Churchill Downs in the first leg of the Triple Crown. And Alec Baldwin and David Letterman watch some movies.

headline: Eliud Kipchoge Runs World’s Fastest Marathon, in Nike’s Special Shoes
text: Even in a highly controlled environment, the sub-two-hour marathon remains elusive — just barely.

headline: French Voters Express Hope, Anger and Frustration
text: There was at least one big question hanging over the French presidential elections on Sunday that could’ve affect the outcome: Would supporters of the defeated far-left candidate Jean-Luc Mélenchon vote for Marine Le Pen or Emmanuel Macron — or abstain altogether?

headline: ‘I Never Dreamed of a World in Which I Was Uninsurable’
text: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment. Some comments were edited for length and clarity.

headline: Inside VW’s Campaign of Trickery
text: This article is adapted from “Faster, Higher, Farther: The Volkswagen Scandal” by Jack Ewing, the European economics correspondent for The New York Times based in Frankfurt. The book, to be published May 23 by W. W. Norton, reveals new details of a broad conspiracy within Volkswagen to cover up the fact that its cars were designed to deceive pollution regulators.

headline: Judy Woodruff, the Woman of the Hour
text: WASHINGTON — It had already been a long day, but Judy Woodruff wasn’t in the mood to slow down.

headline: U.S. Far-Right Activists Promote Hacking Attack Against Macron
text: After months of trying to move the political needle in favor of Marine Le Pen in the French presidential election, American far-right activists on Saturday threw their weight behind a  hacking attack against her rival, Emmanuel Macron, hoping to cast doubt on an election that is pivotal to France and the wider world.

headline: Why I Worship the Weight Watchers Founder Jean Nidetch
text: The day after what I thought was a promising first date with a man I had met online, I received a long text message explaining why exactly he was left with a negative impression of me. The reason was that my online photos were too flattering and didn’t fairly show off what my body looked like in person. He used the word “deceit.” I was, in short, too fat for a second date.

headline: How Fidget Spinners Became a Hula Hoop for Generation Z
text: You had never seen or heard of them before. And then suddenly they were everywhere. Whirring on your children’s fingers. Driving their teachers bonkers. Driving you bonkers. Trending on Twitter. Sold out on Amazon. Herein, a primer on how the cheapo gizmo of the moment spiraled out of control:

headline: What It’s Like to Wear a Three-Armed Jacket
text: Six devotees of Comme des Garçons explain their attraction to the fantastical designs of Rei Kawakubo.

headline: Molly at the Marriott: Inside America’s Premier Psychedelics Conference
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — In a packed, cavernous space one weekend late in April, a crowd of thousands was becoming increasingly amped up. Rainbow hair was commonplace, purple silk pants were sighted, and the smell of marijuana drifted in from a designated smoking area nearby. Audience members watched the stage with avid interest, leaping to occasionally shoeless feet to applaud and cheer.

headline: Capturing the Colorful Style of Punjab, India
text: What keeps Mr. Hartman going back — this was his fifth trip — is his fascination with taking pictures of the Nihang Sikhs. This time, he spent most of his days posted outside the Golden Temple, the highest place of pilgrimage in Sikhism, as well as at the train station in Amritsar and the market in Chandigarh.

headline: The Wrong Way to Fix Student Debt
text: Tens of millions of Americans together owe more than a trillion dollars in student debt. For the financial health of their households and the entire economy, ensuring a fair and smoothly functioning student loan system is critically important.

headline: When That Feisty Neighbor Becomes the President

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Uber Under Scrutiny

headline: Macron Hacking Attack: What We Know and Don’t Know

headline: Noisy Construction in the Building
text: Q. A shareholder in our co-op is combining two apartments. For the past six months, the construction has made our lives miserable, tying up the elevator and disrupting any quiet enjoyment on weekdays from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. The board and the managing agent have shrugged off the concerns of shareholders, and we are at our wits’ end. Is there anything to be done?

headline: Meredith Sellers and Michael Pelster: Together, and Not Just Atop Their Class

headline: In Venezuela’s Chaos, Elites Play a High-Stakes Game for Survival
text: Even as Venezuela sinks into chaos, with clashes between protesters and the police escalating, why have its powerful political and military elites stuck by President Nicolás Maduro?

headline: Stopwatches and Mint Juleps: 17 Years on the Derby
text: Let me tell you about the Kentucky Derby, one of the longest and most pleasurable days in journalism — modern or otherwise — which I’ve been fortunate to cover now for 17 of the past 18 years. (My sole miss, in 2013, was because of my son’s first communion. Apparently the Vatican is not aware that something else very important occurs down here in the Commonwealth on the first Saturday of each May.)

headline: Variety Puzzle: Split Decisions
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Split Decisions is a nice diversion from a week of crossword puzzles, and it highlights the point I made this week about letting your brain fill in missing information.

headline: Hamas Picks Ismail Haniya as Leader as Power Balance Shifts to Gaza
text: JERUSALEM — Ismail Haniya, a longtime leader of Hamas in Gaza, was on Saturday officially named the senior leader of the militant group, which has been trying to soften its public image as it jockeys for influence in the Palestinian territories and internationally.

headline: 5 Years After Crackdown, an Anti-Kremlin Protest Resumes
text: MOSCOW — Pro-Western liberals, hard-line nationalists, gay-rights activists and other Kremlin opponents gathered in central Moscow on Saturday, seeking to revive a broad-based protest movement against President Vladimir V. Putin that was snuffed out five years ago by mass arrests and stiff jail sentences. The demonstrators chanted the one demand that unites their disparate causes: “Russia Without Putin!”

headline: 85-Year-Old Everest Climber, Trying to Reclaim Record, Dies
text: KATHMANDU, Nepal — An octogenarian Nepalese mountaineer who was on a mission to reclaim his title as the oldest climber on Mount Everest died on Saturday afternoon at base camp, government officials said.

headline: ‘No District Is Off the Table’: Health Vote Could Put House in Play
text: WASHINGTON — In a suburban Chicago district, Kelly Mazeski, a breast cancer survivor, used the day of the vote to repeal the Affordable Care Act to announce her House candidacy, vowing to make Representative Peter Roskam pay for his vote “to make Americans pay more and get less for their health care.”

headline: Health Act Repeal Could Threaten U.S. Job Engine
