headline: Heather Phillips, Benjamin Silverman
text: Heather Michele Phillips and Benjamin William Silverman were married May 20 at Diviera Drive, a restaurant in Brooklyn. Perrin Wolfe, a friend of the couple and a minister with American Marriage Ministries, officiated.

headline: Mets’ Bullpen Holds On to Beat the Angels
text: It was a night of milestones for the Mets — Terry Collins’s 1,013th game as their manager, the most in team history, and Jose Reyes’ 2,000th hit — but until the very last pitch, a fastball from Addison Reed that pinch-hitter Danny Espinosa swung through with the bases loaded to secure a 7-5 victory, there was no guarantee of a reason to celebrate.

headline: Kellene Eagen, Brian Schneirow
text: Dr. Kellene Vokaty Eagen and Brian Richard Schneirow were married May 20 at the Log Cabin in the Presidio park in San Francisco. Kathleen H. Eagen, the bride’s sister, was ordained through American Marriage Ministries to officiate.

headline: Ayesha Choudhury, George Gonzalez
text: Ayesha Choudhury and George Arthur Gonzalez were married May 20 at the Montclair Art Museum in Montclair, N.J. Jamal Mahmood, a member of Muslims for Progressive Values performed a Muslim ceremony.

headline: Caroline New, Michael Cappon
text: Caroline Ann New and Michael John Cappon were married May 20 at Bowman’s Hill Wildflower Preserve in New Hope, Pa. Richard A. Cataldi, a friend of the couple who was ordained through American Marriage Ministries for the event, officiated.

headline: Emily Garber, Federico Pastorino
text: Emily Joan Garber and Dr. Federico Pastorino were married May 20. Wendy A. Curran, a justice of the peace in Ridgefield, Conn., officiated there at Lounsbury House.

headline: Warriors Take 3-0 Series Lead on the Depleted Spurs
text: SAN ANTONIO — Gregg Popovich, the coach of the San Antonio Spurs, had concocted a plan to combat the Golden State Warriors on Saturday night.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Twin Peaks’ and ‘Dark Angel’
text: “Twin Peaks” returns, and what it brings with it is perhaps the biggest mystery of all. And Joanne Froggatt — that’s Anna Bates of “Downton Abbey” to you — taps into her sinister side.

headline: On ‘Saturday Night Live,’ Alec Baldwin Sings a Swan Song for Trump
text: It was a night of milestones on “Saturday Night Live,” which in the final episode of its 42nd season, said goodbye to the longtime cast members Bobby Moynihan (who is joining the CBS sitcom “Me, Myself & I”) and Vanessa Bayer (who confirmed her departure in a bittersweet Instagram post).

headline: Writers From the Right and Left React to This Week’s Trump News
text: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. That’s why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $900,000
text: 86 Irma Avenue, Port Washington

headline: North Korea Fires Medium-Range Ballistic Missile
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea fired a missile on Sunday, a week after its successful test of a new intermediate-range ballistic missile, South Korean officials said.

headline: Taliban Launch Rocket Attack and Kill at Least 20 Afghan Police Officers
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In a two-pronged attack in a southern Afghan province, the Taliban shelled the provincial capital city with rockets and then raided police outposts in a neighboring district, killing at least 20 officers and wounding six others, officials said on Sunday.

headline: Trump Softens Tone on Islam but Calls for Purge of ‘Foot Soldiers of Evil’
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — President Trump on Sunday pivoted away from his strident assessment of Islam as a religion of hatred as he sought to redefine American leadership in the Middle East and rally the Muslim world to join him in a renewed campaign against extremism.

headline: The Hardest Job in Politics: Presidential Spokesman
text: Ever since inauguration, the White House has struggled to keep its story straight – and now, communications director Michael Dubke has resigned. Conflicting messages, and President Trump himself, have made it difficult for the communications team to speak on his behalf.

headline: Russia, Comey, Trump: Your Weekend Briefing
text: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: Over 60 and Dancing at W.N.B.A. Center Court
text: The Timeless Torches, a dance squad for the W.N.B.A.’s Liberty, lets those over 40 — many in their 60s — shake their booty on center court, breaking the tradition of the typical halftime act.

headline: ‘To Whom It Should Concern’
text: This is the latest edition of the Race/Related newsletter. To get it in your inbox weekly, sign up here. Tell your friends and share your stories.

headline: 24 Hours of Music, Yoga and Art
text: Spend a day in Arcosanti, Ariz., where the FORM Festival curates more than just the musicians. Attendees must fill out an application to attend the three-day event, which includes meditative mornings and performance art pieces.

headline: A Guide to Staying on Top of Your Student Loan
text: Good advice about student loans can be hard to find: Repayment options can be overwhelming, colleges don’t provide great counseling and loan collectors can be bad actors. That’s why The New York Times has collected some of the best tips, tools and guides for families and students trying to figure out student debt.

headline: President Trump Speaks to Muslim Leaders In Renewed Campaign Against Extremism
text: In a centerpiece speech in Riyadh, President Trump addressed leaders from around the Muslim world.

headline: Democracy, It Turns Out, Suits the Warriors Just Fine
text: SAN ANTONIO — It sounds silly at this point, with the Golden State Warriors on the cusp of a third straight trip to the N.B.A. finals, to suggest that they faced challenges at the start of the season.

headline: Cloud Computing’s Trainer Wins One for His Mentor at Preakness
text: BALTIMORE — You don’t choose your mentors, they choose you. Ask Chad Brown. He was a small-town kid from upstate New York when the trainer Bobby Frankel decided to teach him what he knew.

headline: Off to Italy to Study Painting: A Former Inmate’s Journey
text: JERSEY CITY — “This is my paint gear,” George Anthony Morton said, apologizing for splatters that only he could see on his black T-shirt. He had spent the afternoon at his easel, painting a portrait of someone he had asked to pose for him.

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Democrats in New Jersey Governor’s Race Court Progressive Vote
text: NEWARK — With the heart of his campaign platform coming under repeated attack from Democratic opponents, Philip D. Murphy tried to claim a potent ally.

headline: Erdogan Says He Will Extend His Sweeping Rule Over Turkey
text: ISTANBUL — In a signal that Turkey faces indefinite rule by decree, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan announced on Sunday that a state of emergency, introduced as a temporary measure after last year’s failed coup, would continue until the country achieved “welfare and peace.”

headline: Get Me Rewrite! Now It’s Late-Night Hosts Keeping Up With News
text: Around 5 p.m. last Monday, Steve Bodow, an executive producer at “The Daily Show With Trevor Noah,” was making final tweaks on that night’s script when he saw a breaking news alert from The Washington Post: President Trump had disclosed classified intelligence to Russian officials in a White House meeting.

headline: Afghan Magazine, a Sisterhood of Ideas, Hopes to Counter Men’s Sway
text: The first issue of the Afghan women’s magazine covers standard ground, like fashion tips during pregnancy and interviews with young pop artists about their love lives.

headline: 19 and Coming Into His Own, Until a Fatal Night of Hazing
text: READINGTON, N.J. — Timothy Piazza started out a shy high school student in New Jersey who flushed so deeply scarlet when speaking to a girl that some called him Barney after the purple dinosaur. A growth spurt turned him into a gentle giant, keen to protect more vulnerable peers. He fell in love, became gregarious.

headline: Three Climbers, One American, Die on Mount Everest
text: KATHMANDU, Nepal — Three climbers — one from Alabama, one from Slovakia and the third an Australian — died Sunday on Mount Everest, the world’s highest peak, and an Indian man disappeared while descending, officials and expedition leaders said.

headline: Emboldened by Rouhani’s Win, Iranians Seek Further Reforms
text: TEHRAN — Iranians came out in force to dance in the streets this weekend, breaking Islamic rules, to celebrate the re-election  of President Hassan Rouhani by a large margin.

headline: ‘Alien: Covenant’ Is a Ho-Hum No. 1 at the Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES — Meh. The eighth chapter in 20th Century Fox’s “Alien” series arrived to an estimated $36 million in ticket sales in North America — far from a flop, far from a sizzling hit. “Alien: Covenant,” as the latest film is titled, cost roughly $100 million to make, and has taken in an additional $30.3 million overseas.

headline: Novak Djokovic Picks Andre Agassi to Be His Coach at the French Open
text: ROME — Andre Agassi will be Novak Djokovic’s coach at the French Open, Djokovic announced on Sunday.

headline: Trump in Saudi Arabia
text: President Trump spoke about a renewed effort to stamp out extremism during a centerpiece speech to Muslim leaders in Saudi Arabia on Sunday.

headline: ‘This Wasn’t a Speech About Islam’
text: Two of our opinion writers, Mustafa Akyol in Istanbul and Wajahat Ali in the Washington, D.C. area, watched President Trump’s speech in Saudi Arabia this morning and discussed what they thought it meant for the Middle East, American foreign policy and Muslims around the world.

headline: A New Look at the Top of Women’s Tennis: It’s Wide Open
text: ROME — Asked Sunday if she believed, as the oddsmakers do, that she is the French Open favorite, Simona Halep dissented.

headline: Networks Offer Taste of TV’s Ad Future. Marketers Are Hungry for More.
text: America’s biggest television networks invited advertisers to New York institutions like Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center last week, giving them an early glimpse at their fall lineups and treating them to lavish parties and a parade of stars including Stephen Colbert, Kim Kardashian and Tony Romo, all with the aim of attracting billions of dollars in advertising by the end of the summer.

headline: Republicans Watch Their Step in a Slow Retreat From Trump
text: WASHINGTON — Republicans on Sunday inched away from President Trump amid mounting evidence that he may have sought to interfere in the federal investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 election.

headline: No, Google’s Not a Bird: Bringing the Internet to Rural India
text: TARADAND, India — Babulal Singh Neti was sitting with his uncle on a recent afternoon, trying to persuade him of the merits of the internet.

headline: White House, Saudi Arabia, North Korea: Your Morning Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Pittsburgh Welcomed Uber’s Driverless Car Experiment. Not Anymore.
text: PITTSBURGH — When Uber picked this former Rust Belt town as the inaugural city for its driverless car experiment, Pittsburgh played the consummate host.

headline: Notre Dame Students Walk Out of Mike Pence Commencement Address
text: A large crowd of students walked out of the Notre Dame commencement ceremony on Sunday in protest of the speaker, Vice President Mike Pence, who delivered a speech that mixed platitudes about bright, dream-filled futures with a lengthy rebuke of political correctness on college campuses.

headline: Tom Hardy to Star in ‘Venom’
text: He played a formidable villain for DC Comics, and now he’ll do the same for Marvel: Tom Hardy has signed on to lead “Venom,” a spinoff movie in Marvel’s expanding universe.

headline: A Black Actor in ‘Virginia Woolf’? Not Happening, Albee Estate Says
text: A decision by the estate of Edward Albee not to allow a production of “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?” to cast a black actor as a blond character is reigniting decades-long debates in the theater world over race, casting and authorial control.

headline: Wind Project in Wyoming Envisions Coal Miners as Trainees
text: Goldwind Americas, an arm of a leading wind-turbine manufacturer based in China, has been expanding its business in the United States. It has been careful to seek out local, American workers for permanent jobs on the wind farms it supplies.

headline: Review: Future and Migos, Onstage With Their Hits on Shuffle
text: In January, the Atlanta trio Migos ascended to the top of the Billboard Hot 100 with “Bad and Boujee,” one of their signature choppy anthems, bolstered by meme-friendly opening lyrics. The next month, the Atlanta elder Future pulled off something no artist ever had: debuting atop the Billboard album chart in two consecutive weeks with two different albums, ”Future” followed by “Hndrxx.”

headline: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: Andrea Petersen on Living With, and Studying, Anxiety
text: Toward the end of 1989, Andrea Petersen, then a sophomore at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, was “transformed from a slightly silly sorority girl to a terrorized shut-in in just a few weeks’ time.” That’s how she describes the onset of panic attacks and their confusing aftermath in “On Edge,” her new memoir about having what was eventually diagnosed as several forms of anxiety. The book also looks back at the history of our understanding of the various disorders under the umbrella of anxiety, and surveys the latest attempts to combat them. Below, Petersen, a contributing writer at The Wall Street Journal, tells how she overcame worries about disclosing her experiences, what’s changed (and what hasn’t) in treatment, and more.

headline: A ‘Bachelorette’ Bible
text: There is a mantra often repeated on “The Bachelor” and its spinoff, “The Bachelorette”: “Here for the right reasons.” Contestants who go on the show to put their trust in “the process,” find true love and settle down are “here for the right reasons.” Those who come to take off their tops, boost their Instagram followings and land hosting gigs on the spring break party circuit are not.

headline: Pippa Middleton’s Wedding Dress: What Is the Story?
text: When does an ostensibly private family event become fair game for media attention? This perennial question for the global press — and its readership — was raised once again this past weekend, when Pippa Middleton, younger sister to Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, married James Matthews in Berkshire, England.

headline: Profiles of Six Candidates for New Jersey Governor
text: A former ambassador, a state senator and a lieutenant governor are all in the race.

headline: What You Really Want to Know About the Candidates for New Jersey Governor

headline: Camping Aid
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — It’s not unusual for children to develop a passion for certain things, especially if the things are tool-like in nature and come with all sorts of moving, interesting parts.

headline: Aaron Judge, His Bat Dulled, Makes Brilliant Catch in Yankees Win
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — When the Yankees’ Aaron Judge takes his place on a baseball field, he cuts a larger-than-life figure. He stands 6 feet 7 inches, weighs 275 pounds and is so rock solid that when he ran into a wall at Fenway Park recently, Manager Joe Girardi said he was concerned for the wall.

headline: Mets Take a Beating From the Angels as Tommy Milone Falters
text: Throughout the weekend, Mets Manager Terry Collins spoke reverently of Angels outfielder Mike Trout, perhaps the most feared hitter in baseball.

headline: Review: Squeezing Music Made for One Hall Into the Geffen
text: The end of the New York Philharmonic’s season is near and with it the close of Alan Gilbert’s tenure as music director. With his final appearances at Lincoln Center, he seems to be working through items on a bucket list, among them performances of a full Wagner opera (“Das Rheingold,” starting June 1) and a political statement in the form of concerts (beginning June 7) featuring musicians from Iran, Iraq and Israel, among other countries. On Friday Mr. Gilbert fulfilled another wish: to finally bring to David Geffen Hall the mating call of the male plainfin midshipman.

headline: Why Send Germany a Statue of Marx? The Chinese Have Some Ideas
text: BEIJING — From China, with love. Or something more insidious?

headline: It Was Hard This Year to Keep Politics Out of High School Yearbooks
text: A high school yearbook is a keepsake. Like an Instagram filter, it’s meant to bathe recent memories in the warm, soft-focus glow of nostalgia. As an object, it evokes affection and community; you hope to show it to your children and grandchildren someday. A yearbook isn’t supposed to be divisive.

headline: Bringing the Dream of an Elite College to Rural Students
text: SAMPSON COUNTY, N.C. — The first time Nyreke Peters met the new college adviser at his rural high school, he was skeptical. Other adults at Hobbton High School spoke with the same Southern accent and shared an easygoing familiarity that came from having gone to the same schools and having spent their lives in the same county.

headline: In Wreckage of the Fyre Festival, Fury, Lawsuits and an Inquiry
text: A few days after the spectacular collapse of the Fyre Festival, just as federal investigators began to circle the wreckage, the event’s would-be mastermind, Billy McFarland, was still making promises.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of May 22
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Lack of Workers, Not Work, Weighs on the Nation’s Economy
text: SALT LAKE CITY — Stephanie Pappas and her brothers built their roofing supply company in this fast-growing region by promising next-day delivery, but lately they’ve been forced to tell some customers that tomorrow is impossible.

headline: Liverpool Chases Away Butterflies to Earn a Champions League Berth
text: LIVERPOOL, England — Only when the second goal came could the home crowd at Anfield finally, guardedly allow itself to breathe. The atmosphere had been taut until that moment, close to an hour into Sunday’s match — Liverpool’s Premier League finale against Middlesbrough.

headline: In Comeback, Pedro Sánchez Is Re-elected Leader of Spanish Socialists
text: MADRID — The ousted leader of Spain’s main opposition Socialist Party, Pedro Sánchez, made a remarkable comeback on Sunday, winning re-election as party leader only seven months after stepping down in defeat.

headline: Roxcy Bolton, Feminist Crusader for Equality, Including in Naming Hurricanes, Dies at 90
text: Roxcy Bolton, a pioneering and tempestuous Florida feminist who was credited with founding the nation’s first rape treatment center and who helped persuade national weather forecasters not to name tropical storms after only women, died on May 17 in Coral Gables, Fla. She was 90.

headline: A Vital Drug Runs Low, Though Its Base Ingredient Is in Many Kitchens
text: Hospitals around the country are scrambling to stockpile vials of a critical drug — even postponing operations or putting off chemotherapy treatments — because the country’s only two suppliers have run out.

headline: Cuomo Calls on Trump to Ease Penn Station’s ‘Summer of Agony’
text: Saying conditions at Pennsylvania Station in New York have reached a crisis, and that planned track closings would lead to “a summer of agony,” Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo appealed to President Trump on Sunday to recognize the situation as an emergency and provide funding for construction and transportation alternatives for commuters.

headline: Preparations for Trump’s Visit Expose Political Rifts in Israel
text: JERUSALEM — Unlike the royal pomp and ceremony with which President Trump was greeted over the weekend in Saudi Arabia, the plans for his arrival on Monday in Israel had devolved into an unseemly political ruckus before Air Force One touched down.

headline: Billboard Music Awards Red Carpet
text: See what Vanessa Hudgens, Halsey, John Legend and more wore to the show in Las Vegas.

headline: Plotting an O’Reilly Comeback With an Eye on Fox
text: Two decades ago, Bill O’Reilly’s wryly resentful Everyman act became the foundation upon which the Fox News founder Roger Ailes built the right-leaning television monopoly that the network became (and remains today).

headline: OPEC Ministers Will Meet, and Few Surprises Are Expected From the Fed
text: Here’s a look at what’s coming up this week.

headline: In Saudi Arabia, Trump Reaches Out to Sunni Nations, at Iran’s Expense
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — As voters in Iran danced in the streets, celebrating the landslide re-election of a moderate as president, President Trump stood in front of a gathering of leaders from across the Muslim world and called on them to isolate a nation he said had “fueled the fires of sectarian conflict and terror.”

headline: Ivanka Trump Swayed the President on Family Leave. Congress Is a Tougher Sell.
text: Ivanka Trump has largely cast herself as a behind-the-scenes force for moderation in the West Wing, but this week she will take her first real political risk when her signature parental leave plan is presented to a conservative House majority hostile to any new government mandates.

headline: After 146 Years, Ringling Brothers Circus Takes Its Final Bow
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — The lights went up on the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey circus on Sunday evening to reveal 14 lions and tigers sitting in a circle, surrounding a man in a sparkling suit. It was a sight too implausible to seem real yet such an iconic piece of Americana that it was impossible to believe the show would not go on.

headline: After Fleeing Bias at Home, Gay Russians Say It Persists in Brooklyn
text: For many years, Denis Kruglenko treated life as if it were a delicately calibrated performance. A gay man living in Belgorod, Russia, he knew that even appearing to be homosexual could be perilous. He did what he could to conceal his sexual orientation but it never seemed to be enough. Once, he was beaten up for wearing a pair of pink socks.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Shifting Tone, President Saves Dark Words for a Faith’s Fringe
text: “Love your shoes. Boy, those shoes. Man!”

headline: Apple Pay Violates Patents Held by Security Technology Inventor, Lawsuit Alleges
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A small Boston company, founded by the inventor of a popular corporate encryption technology called RSA SecurID, sued Apple and Visa on Sunday, arguing that the Apple Pay digital payment technology violates its patents.

headline: Caught in White House Chaos, Justice Dept. Official Seeks Neutral Ground
text: WASHINGTON — Last month, Rod J. Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general at the center of the crisis building around President Trump’s White House, gathered with federal prosecutors and law enforcement officials to bid farewell to his old job, United States attorney in Maryland, and celebrate his new one.

headline: ‘The Leftovers’ Season 3, Episode 6 Recap: The End Is Near
text: After this week’s episode of “The Leftovers,” there are only two hours of TV time — give or take a few minutes — for creators Damon Lindelof and Tom Perrotta to reach some kind of resolution. But for a show so steeped in the eternal mysteries of faith, doubt and spiritual fulfillment, what does a “resolution” even look like?

headline: Review: ‘The Whirligig’ Is a Feast for Actors, by a Knowing Chef
text: Hamish Linklater, the author of the new play “The Whirligig,” is best known as an actor. And for the overstuffed drama that opened on Sunday night at the Pershing Square Signature Center, he has whipped up a multicourse meal for fellow actors to feast upon.

headline: The Censors’ Disappearing Vibrator
text: SINGAPORE — Nobody told me that the format of “The Ellen DeGeneres Show” had changed, so imagine my surprise one recent afternoon when the credits appeared after only 30 minutes of dancing and funny videos. I discovered later that the second half of this episode featured two segments with celebrity guests that did not survive the Singapore censors’ scrutiny: Jane Fonda wielding a vibrator and Asia Kate Dillon discussing her nonbinary gender identity, both considered too taboo for daytime television here.

headline: Review: In ‘Twin Peaks,’ an Old Log Learns Some New Tricks
text: One of the creepiest images in the new “Twin Peaks” is a glass box, ensconced in a window in New York City, which is kept under constant observation in case something comes through it. (Not-such-a-spoiler alert: Something does.)

headline: Huntsman Is Said to Be Close to Merger With Clariant
text: The Huntsman Corporation is close to a deal to merge with a Swiss counterpart, Clariant, and create a large trans-Atlantic chemical maker at a time of consolidation within the industry, a person briefed on the matter said Sunday evening.

headline: No Corrections: May 22, 2017
text: No corrections appeared in print.

headline: As Profit Dwindles, Ford Is Said to Replace Its C.E.O.
text: (Editors’ note: Ford on Monday announced the replacement of its chief executive, Mark Fields, vowing to catch up in the race to build self-driving cars and define a new era in personal mobility.)

headline: Pediatricians Say No Fruit Juice in Child’s First Year
text: The nation’s top pediatricians are advising parents to stop giving fruit juice to children in the first year of life, saying the drink is not as healthful as many parents think.

headline: Anarchists Fill Services Void Left by Faltering Greek Governance
text: ATHENS — It may seem paradoxical, but Greece’s anarchists are organizing like never before.

headline: Saudi Arabia, Hassan Rouhani, Real Madrid: Your Monday Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘The Bachelorette’ and ‘Carpool Karaoke’
text: Drum roll, please: “The Bachelorette” introduces Rachel Lindsay, its first black lead. Sterling K. Brown navigates a frozen Colorado with Bear Grylls. And James Corden drives his ‘Carpool Karaoke’ into prime time.

headline: Word + Quiz: aseptic
From Hockey 101 to a Ph.D. in Nashville
text: NASHVILLE — In the beginning, before the Nashville Predators sank their fangs into a city that adored hockey but just didn’t know it yet, there was a kiosk. Nat Harden perched there, outside the food court of the CoolSprings mall in suburban Brentwood, eight hours a day, five days a week during the 1997 holiday season and tried to sell a sport that he had never seen in person and a team that had no players.

headline: Museum of the Future: Portable and Personal
text: Dayanita Singh has spent the past decade creating customizable photo books that are a portable exhibit and catalog in one.

headline: Donald Trump, Our A.I. President
text: It is hard to imagine a more scathing indictment of our ability to read another’s thoughts and intentions than our inability to predict Donald Trump’s next move. From the gross pre-election misjudgments to postelection bafflement, the best pundits are at a loss to accurately anticipate his response to matters like North Korean military aggressiveness or his moment-by-moment political gyrations and opinion reversals. Labeling Trump a narcissist, psychopath, megalomaniac or attention-impaired, or all of the above, might feel explanatory, but even when armed with the best psychoanalytic insights, we have no idea what he will do when presented with a new or unforeseen circumstance.

headline: Lurching Backward on Justice Reform
text: When it comes to criminal justice, Attorney General Jeff Sessions is a man out of time — stuck defiantly in the 1980s, when crime in America was high and politicians scrambled to out-tough one another by passing breathtakingly severe sentencing laws. This mind-set was bad enough when Mr. Sessions was a senator from Alabama working to thwart sentencing reforms in Congress. Now that he is the nation’s top law enforcement officer, he’s trying to drag the country backward with him, even as most states are moving toward more enlightened policies.

headline: China and India Make Big Strides on Climate Change
text: Until recently, China and India have been cast as obstacles, at the very least reluctant conscripts, in the battle against climate change. That reputation looks very much out-of-date now that both countries have greatly accelerated their investments in cost-effective renewable energy sources — and reduced their reliance on fossil fuels. It’s America — Donald Trump’s America — that now looks like the laggard.

headline: How the Swastika Became a Confederate Flag
text: The easy-listening white supremacists who surged out of the shadows during the presidential campaign are no less dangerous than their white power survivalist or raving skinhead counterparts. But they are hoping to rebrand themselves by wearing business clothes and attempting to sound reasonable as they advance a racist agenda. The debate about removing monuments to white supremacy that were built throughout the South a century or more ago is tailor-made for this tactic.

headline: Tired of New York’s Subways? Blame Andrew Cuomo
text: When the Metropolitan Transportation Authority opened the Second Avenue Subway extension in January, Gov. Andrew Cuomo was quick to put his stamp on the new line. At news conferences, inaugural rides and even a star-studded New Year’s Eve party, the governor branded the project as his own.

headline: Blood in the Water
text: Donald Trump has left the country for his first foreign trip as president and what he has left behind is a brewing crisis that appears to deepen by the day, and even the hour.

headline: The Unfreeing of American Workers
text: American conservatives love to talk about freedom. Milton Friedman’s famous pro-capitalist book and TV series were titled “Free to Choose.” And the hard-liners in the House pushing for a complete dismantling of Obamacare call themselves the Freedom Caucus.

headline: Museum of the Future: Portable and Personal
text: Dayanita Singh is a photographer, but creating images is just a fraction of her artistic practice.

headline: Bangkok Hospital Bombing Wounds 24 on Anniversary of Thai Coup
text: BANGKOK — A bomb wounded 24 people at a military-owned hospital in Bangkok on Monday, the third anniversary of the army’s seizing power in Thailand.

headline: Questions for: ‘The 5 ‘Handsome Girls’ Trying to Be China’s Biggest Boy Band’
text: Article: The 5 ‘Handsome Girls’ Trying to Be China’s Biggest Boy Band

headline: The Order of Lenin: ‘Find Some Truly Hard People’
text: “Archives are power,” Kirill Mikhailovich Anderson, the former director of the Russian State Archive of Socio-Political History in Moscow, once remarked to me. He was talking about the first director of the Marx-Engels Institute, founded in 1919: An old Bolshevik, David Riazanov had little patience for the Communist Party officials who constantly demanded documents either to confirm ideological positions or to blacken enemies.

headline: Huntsman Agrees to Merge With Clariant of Switzerland
text: LONDON — The Huntsman Corporation said on Monday that it had agreed to merge with Clariant of Switzerland, continuing a consolidation push in the chemicals industry.

headline: Indonesia Police Arrest 141 Men Accused of Having Gay Sex Party
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The police in Indonesia have arrested 141 men at a sauna in the capital on suspicion of having a gay sex party, the latest crackdown on homosexuality in the country.

headline: What Are Your Expectations About Earning, Saving and Spending Money?
text: What attitudes do you and your peers have toward saving and spending money? Are there any common expectations that you have identified regarding the types of jobs and salaries you will one day have and the kinds of lifestyles you hope to have?

headline: Want Family Travel to Really Count? Make a Plan
text: When the first of her three children neared age 8, and school events and sports increasingly demanded the family’s time, Tracy Krechevsky, 52, a teacher in Wellesley, Mass., decided they needed a plan to make the most of their vacations.

headline: An ‘Awesome’ View at America’s First Offshore Wind Farm
text: Take a ride out to Block Island Wind Farm and follow an engineer to the top of a wind turbine in this 360° video. Built by Deepwater Wind, the project tests the viability of large-scale wind farming along the New England coast.

headline: A 17th-Century Witch Hunter and His Campaign of Terror
text: THE WITCHFINDER’S SISTER By Beth Underdown 312 pp. Ballantine Books. $28

headline: 50 Years On, Stories of the Six Day War and What Came After
text: What new insight can a bunch of Very Important Writers provide about the Israeli occupation of the West Bank? Phrased a little differently — Michael Chabon and Ayelet Waldman call these novelists and essayists “storytellers” — this is the question the two editors of KINGDOM OF OLIVES AND ASH: Writers Confront the Occupation (Harper Perennial, paper, $16.99) decided to pose on the occupation’s 50th anniversary. (Moriel Rothman-Zecher was associate editor.) They gathered their friends, most of whom, they admit, had never given the occupation “more than a glancing consideration,” and took them on weeklong tours of East Jerusalem, the village of Susiya in the south Hebron hills and the cities of Hebron and Ramallah, all flash points where Israeli control over Palestinian lives can be felt acutely. The result is an exhausting collection of essays. And with a few strong exceptions — like the pieces by Dave Eggers, Rachel Kushner and Waldman herself — they are what you might expect: fairly superficial, full of unearned authority and exhibitionist empathy. A parachute job.

headline: White House Moves to Block Ethics Inquiry Into Ex-Lobbyists on Payroll
text: The Trump administration, in a significant escalation of its clash with the government’s top ethics watchdog, has moved to block an effort to disclose the names of former lobbyists who have been granted waivers to work in the White House or federal agencies.

headline: Bill Cosby Trial: Five Jurors Are Chosen in a Painstaking Process
text: PITTSBURGH — Sorting through a jury pool already exposed to the blaze of publicity over allegations against Bill Cosby, lawyers and a judge on Monday selected the first five jurors, all of them white, who will weigh whether he committed a sexual assault.

headline: Alone on the Open Road: Truckers Feel Like ‘Throwaway People’
text: EFFINGHAM, Ill. — The vast Petro truck stop here is a neon-lit, blacktop oasis at the crossroads of America. It beckons big-rig drivers with showers, laundry machines, a barber shop, even a knife store. “Professional drivers only,” reads the sign above the tables of the Iron Skillet restaurant, where truckers sit mostly alone, carrying the solitude of their jobs into an otherwise social setting.

headline: Movie Ticket Sales Sagging? Time to Bring Out the Toys
text: BURBANK, Calif. — The once-catatonic corner of moviedom dedicated to merchandise has suddenly come alive as studios — walloped by vanishing DVD sales and determined to keep fans engaged between sequels — look at themed toys, clothes and home décor with renewed vigor.

text: The president has backtracked on several issues that are key to Israel, including the location of the U.S. Embassy and settlement-building.

text: WASHINGTON, May 21. — President Johnson gathered some of the most luminous intellectuals on his payroll around a lunch table the other day to find out why he was having trouble communicating with the country’s luminous intellectuals.

headline: Monographie’s Fall/Winter 2017 Collection
text: A new line of shirting from a Céline alum.

headline: Brand to Know: The Line That Focuses Only on Shirting
text: “You know, when you do a mono-product line, you need to feel inspired by it,” says Aude Castéja, the French designer behind the young brand Monographie. Her line is “mono” in that every garment is a riff on the same concept: shirting. In some cases, she has cut fabric away at the shoulders, while other pieces feature a bib front, an off-center opening or a series of cuffs stacked surreally up the sleeve. “There are so many options,” she says of the shirt’s possibilities. “I feel it’s endless.”

headline: The Science of Adolescent Sleep
text: Why do children wake up early when they are young but want to stay in bed till noon as teenagers?

headline: The Worst Fat in the Food Supply
text: As strange as it may seem to someone who is not a chemist, the movement of a single hydrogen atom from one side of a molecule to the other can change a simple, naturally occurring food ingredient into a deadly substance.

headline: New York Today: Birding by Subway
text: Good morning on this misty Monday.

headline: Trump Comes to Israel Citing a Palestinian Deal as Crucial
text: JERUSALEM — President Trump began a two-day visit to Israel on Monday with a blunt assessment for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu: If Israel really wants peace with its Arab neighbors, the cost will be resolving the generations-old standoff with the Palestinians.

headline: Editorial Contest Winner | ‘The Collateral Damage of Defending Democracy’
text: We are honoring each of the Top 10 winners of our Fourth Annual Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay a day. You can find them all here.

headline: Letter to Office of Government Ethics
text: The White House, in an extremely unusual move, asked the Office of Government Ethics to hold off on its investigation into ethics waivers granted to ex-lobbyists and industry lawyers.

headline: Seattle Climbs but Austin Sprawls: The Myth of the Return to Cities
text: Be skeptical when you hear about the return to glory of the American city — that idealized vision of rising skyscrapers and bustling, dense downtowns. Contrary to perception, the nation is continuing to become more suburban, and at an accelerating pace. The prevailing pattern is growing out, not up, although with notable exceptions.

headline: In Britain, Pippa Middleton Gets Married in Giles Deacon
text: The English designer only recently moved his focus into couture.

headline: The Pippa Middleton Wedding Dress Effect
text: It was a big weekend for red-carpet people-watching — what with the Cannes Film Festival, President Trump’s first trip abroad since taking office, and the Billboard Music Awards — but for all the competition, the fashion moment I am still thinking about on Monday morning was the “not-quite-royal-wedding-of-the-year,” a.k.a. the nuptials of Pippa Middleton, sister of Catherine, the Duchess of Cambridge, with James Matthews.

headline: North Korea Missile Test Was Short on Distance but Long on Data, South Says
text: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korean defense officials said on Monday that the missile the North launched on Sunday was a medium-range ballistic missile that cannot fly far enough to strike American military bases in Guam, as analysts had feared.

text: Good morning.

headline: Ford, Trudging Into the Future, Ousts Mark Fields as C.E.O.
text: DEARBORN, Mich. — Ford Motor was the American automaker savvy enough to avoid bankruptcy when industry sales collapsed during the 2008 financial crisis. Then it rode economic recovery and cheap gasoline to record sales and profits. But what looks like success can turn upside down quickly in Detroit these days.

headline: Officials Decline to Call Fatal Stabbing of Black Student a Hate Crime
text: The police found the white man, a student at the University of Maryland, at around 3:30 a.m. Saturday, sitting on a campus bench a few feet away from the spot where witnesses said he had plunged his knife into a black man’s chest.

headline: Drilling for a Dream in Myanmar
text: NGA NAUNG MONE, Myanmar — Soon after dawn, Win Myint Oo, bleary-eyed and wearing just a longyi, a traditional Burmese sarong, starts a generator and squats on a bamboo platform suspended under a 40-foot, jury-rigged derrick: just three steel poles and bamboo struts lashed together with rope.

headline: A Reunion for the Lundqvist Brothers, and a Gold for Team Sweden
text: COLOGNE, Germany — Henrik Lundqvist is 40 minutes older than his twin brother, Joel. That meant that Henrik, 35, was officially the oldest member of Sweden’s team at the men’s hockey world championship.

headline: Ai Weiwei’s Lego Portraits of Activists Head to the Hirshhorn Museum
text: Ai Weiwei, the provocative and politically minded Chinese artist who has two major projects coming soon to New York City, has another big installation to add to his busy year: the East Coast debut of “Trace” (2014), which will open at the Smithsonian’s Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in June.

headline: Nearly 20 Million Have Gained Health Insurance Since 2010
text: The number of Americans without health insurance has fallen drastically in recent years, according to new data from the National Center for Health Statistics.

headline: Celtics’ Upset of Cavaliers Stretches Out a Foregone Conclusion
text: So the Boston Celtics beat the Cavaliers, in Cleveland, on Sunday night despite being 16-point underdogs. And they did it in their first game without their star, Isaiah Thomas, who is out for the season with a hip injury.

headline: Some Social Scientists Are Tired of Asking for Permission
text: If you took Psychology 101 in college, you probably had to enroll in an experiment to fulfill a course requirement or to get extra credit. Students are the usual subjects in social science research — made to play games, fill out questionnaires, look at pictures and otherwise provide data points for their professors’ investigations into human behavior, cognition and perception.

headline: In ‘Enormous Success,’ Scientists Tie 52 Genes to Human Intelligence
text: In a significant advance in the study of mental ability, a team of European and American scientists announced on Monday that they had identified 52 genes linked to intelligence in nearly 80,000 people.

headline: Make It Delicious
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: A Gadget Favored by Fingers Both Fidgety and Sticky
text: They are kept behind the counter at the 7-Eleven store on the Upper East Side, out of reach and available only by request, like cigarettes and lottery tickets and chewing tobacco. So close, yet so far from the restless fingers that crave them the most.

headline: Justices Reject 2 Gerrymandered North Carolina Districts, Citing Racial Bias
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court struck down two North Carolina congressional districts on Monday, ruling that lawmakers had violated the Constitution by relying too heavily on race in drawing them, in a decision that could affect many voting maps, generally in the South.

headline: Citigroup Agrees to $97.4 Million Settlement in Money Laundering Inquiry
text: For years, Citigroup employees feared that millions of dollars the bank was moving to Mexico might be suspicious. Yet in many cases, the bank did not alert regulators or step up its monitoring for money laundering, federal prosecutors said Monday.

headline: Iran’s President Mocks Trump’s Saudi Arabia Trip as ‘Just a Show’
text: TEHRAN — Flush from his decisive re-election victory, Iran’s president struck back on Monday after a weekend of verbal affronts from the Saudi-American summit meeting, describing President Trump’s visit to Riyadh as empty theatrics and mocking his support for a monarchy that has “never seen a ballot box.”

headline: “Joel Meyerowitz: Towards Colour 1962-1978”
text: A new show in London explores a pioneer of color photography — and the vivid images he produced.

headline: The ’60s Photographer Who Captured the Street in Vivid Color
text: In 1962, Joel Meyerowitz left his job in advertising and set out to be a photographer. He started by venturing outside with two Leica cameras (one loaded with color film and the other with black and white) to snap the world in motion: In one image, a man strides through the streets of New York cradling an enormous dog in his arms; in another, a couple zooms through Greece on a scooter, the woman’s scarf blurred by the wind.

headline: A New Book Celebrates America’s Brunch Drink
text: Nothing is easier than a Bloody Mary: Open a can of tomato-based mix, add vodka and garnish with a celery stick. It is about the only drink for which I would use a premixed base, and in a pinch I have been known to start with diluted ketchup. In this new book, you’ll find a guide to assembling the classic Bloody Mary and the freedom to experiment with variations like a Korean version seasoned with kimchi purée, a garden-fresh take with muddled cherry tomatoes, or a tomato water “martini.” The drink’s history and bar snacks are included. The broiled Parmesan-shallot toasts deserve to be added to the repertoire: “The Bloody Mary Book” by Ellen Brown (Running Press, $18).

headline: What Was That Glowing Orb Trump Touched in Saudi Arabia?
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — A mysterious glowing orb is exerting uncanny power over the world’s social media.

headline: Snacks From an East Village Wine Bar Available Online
text: At Lois, a tap-only wine bar in the East Village, customers can nibble snacks like candied pepitas with a glass of white. Popular demand has inspired the owners, Nora O’Malley and Phoebe Connell, to produce and sell their crisps, crackers and candied nuts to a wider world. Candied Sichuan pecans with a veneer of spice, dusky rye crackers, and sourdough crackers that beg for cheese are particularly addictive: Aida Pantry Staples, $8 to $10 each, all five for $46, aidaeats.com.

headline: Celebrating Carmelita Maracci, Who ‘Took the Girdle Off Ballet’
text: Pulling off as many as 13 perfect pirouettes on pointe is astonishingly hard, but was simply a matter of course for Carmelita Maracci. Still, the day she did 17, students in the ballet class she was teaching in Los Angeles hoisted her aloft and ran triumphantly down Hollywood Boulevard. Or so the story goes.

headline: What Critics Are Saying About the New ‘Twin Peaks’
text: In the weeks leading up to Showtime’s anxiously awaited “Twin Peaks: The Return,” critics seized the opportunity to spend time with David Lynch’s original series, recapping and reappraising and recounting the behind-the-scenes story of the game-changing mystery that premiered on ABC in 1990. The one thing they couldn’t do was review the new series — because, in true Lynchian fashion, no advance screeners were distributed to the media. (On Friday, there was an embargoed premiere screening in Los Angeles.)

headline: 629,000 Overstayed U.S. Visas Last Year, Homeland Security Says
text: WASHINGTON — An estimated 629,000 visitors to the United States — just over 1 percent of all travelers — remained in the country at the end of last year after overstaying their visas as students, workers or tourists, according to a report released on Monday by the Department of Homeland Security.

headline: Creamy, Dreamy Sorbet Sandwiches for Hot Summer Nights
text: For a warm-weather treat, the pastry chef Marc Aumont is now making macaron sorbet sandwiches at the sweets shop next door to Gabriel Kreuther’s restaurant. Cheesecake sorbet is a name that doesn’t quite do justice to the delectable frozen confection at the center of these crisp, feather-light cookie sandwiches. A subtle tang from the Philadelphia cream cheese used in the sorbet comes through in the plain version, but less so with the berry or pistachio. The chocolate filling is his dark chocolate sorbet, no cheese: Frozen Macaron Sandwiches, $6.50, Kreuther Handcrafted Chocolate, 43 West 42nd Street, 212-201-1985, kreutherchocolate.com.

headline: How to Make It Known There’s a Problem With an App
text: Q. Is there any way to report problems or get technical support for a mobile app?

headline: Food Waste Is the Topic of Conversation at 92nd Street Y
text: The chef Mads Refslund and the professional forager Tama Matsuoka Wong will reveal techniques for putting discarded items like cabbage cores, potato skins and coffee grounds to tasty use during a talk at the 92nd Street Y, as they have done in their new book, “Scraps, Wilt & Weeds: Turning Wasted Food Into Plenty.” There will also be a book signing: Mads Refslund and Tama Matsuoka Wong, June 6, 7 p.m., 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue (92nd Street), tickets $29, 212-415-5500, 92y.org.

headline: Gadget Makes Peeling Eggs a Tad Easier
text: This clever plastic egg peeler really works. Place a hard-cooked egg in the container, add a little water, cover and shake up and down until the sound the egg makes diminishes. Then it will be a cinch to peel. Without the Connecticut-made gadget, invented by a home cook with too many deviled eggs to prepare, you could use a jelly jar with some water almost as effectively: The Negg, $17.99, neggmaker.com.

headline: Daily Report: Cleaning Up the Internet
text: The internet has been a powerful engine for spreading information. It has also spread online harassment and fake news and fed other toxic digital behavior.

headline: Harry Styles Becomes 2nd One Direction Member With a Solo No. 1
text: During its reign as the pre-eminent boy band of the 2010s, One Direction scored four No. 1 albums. Now two of its former members have also reached the top.

headline: Who Is Sheriff Clarke of Milwaukee County? A Brief Guide
text: David A. Clarke Jr., the sheriff of Milwaukee County, was back in the news last week after announcing that he had been appointed to the Department of Homeland Security. (The Trump administration itself has not confirmed the appointment.)

headline: Trump Seeks Delay of Ruling on Health Law Subsidies, Prolonging Uncertainty
text: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration asked a federal appeals court on Monday to delay ruling on a lawsuit that could determine whether the government will continue paying subsidies under the Affordable Care Act to health insurance companies for the benefit of low-income people — effectively prolonging uncertainty that is already rattling the health law.

headline: At Olmsted, a Living Memory of a Farm-to-Table Meal
text: For Greg Baxtrom, the chef and owner of Olmsted in Brooklyn, farm-to-table is as close as his restaurant’s backyard. There he raises herbs, radishes, asparagus and other produce. Mr. Baxtrom recently took over an adjacent plot, built a greenhouse and expanded his harvest with berries, carrots and sprouts. For a $10 fee, customers can dig up an herb or pepper plant and take it home in a special little crate. “People can participate and take a memory away,” Mr. Baxtrom said. Diners must also transplant a seedling from the greenhouse to the garden spot where they have removed their plant. Proceeds go to GrowNYC, the environmental organization that runs the city’s Greenmarkets: Olmsted, 659 Vanderbilt Avenue (Park Place), Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, 718-552-2610, olmstednyc.com.

headline: Microblading, Tattoos, Extensions: The Answer to an Easier Morning
text: Despite the loud Instagram makeup trends that continue to rage, a lot of women are feeling a disconnect. They simply want to make it out the door feeling as if they are relatively put together. Because, let’s be honest, who has the time?

headline: St. Paul’s School Acknowledges Decades of Sexual Misconduct
text: There was an English teacher, the investigators said, who groped a student and had a sexual relationship with another. A female student said a music teacher sexually touched her in his car. And there was a sacred studies teacher, a minister, whom one student accused of rape.

headline: Jim Hackett, Ford’s New C.E.O., Has a History of Turnaround Stories
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Jim Hackett made his career by turning Steelcase, an office-furniture maker in Michigan, into one of America’s most admired companies. More recently, he rejuvenated one of the country’s most storied college athletic programs, at the University of Michigan, and hired its high-profile football coach, Jim Harbaugh.

headline: Barnard Chooses a Leader Whose Research Focuses on Women
text: Barnard College announced on Monday that it had hired Sian Beilock to be its next president, the eighth person to hold the position.

headline: A Taste for Poison in Warmer Climates?
text: Q. Why does venom seem to be more favored as a defense by animals in warmer latitudes?

headline: Staffing Imbalances Reveal New York Jail’s Growing Pains
text: In a swirl of scandals and struggles to address violence on Rikers Island, Mayor Bill de Blasio has poured resources into New York City’s Correction Department, hoping to right the ship. More than 1,000 officers have been added during the mayor’s term, and the department has recorded a sharp rise in its civilian head count for oversight, new programs and overhauls.

headline: Arconic Settles With Elliott After Bruising and Public Dispute
text: Arconic has grappled with a lot over the last year.

headline: Knicks Will Not Renew Contract of Josh Longstaff, an Assistant Coach
text: The N.B.A. is a league built, in part, on the work of assistant coaches, some with shiny names from their playing careers and some who remain anonymous, doing most of their work in the shadows. Josh Longstaff was one such assistant, a member of the Knicks’ coaching staff for the past three seasons who focused on player development.

headline: U.S. Nuclear History Offers Clues to North Korea’s Progress
text: It started with Einstein. His famous E = mc2 revealed a vast asymmetry in the cosmic relationship between matter and energy. In time, experts looked into the possibility of exploiting the disparity.

text: summary

headline: We All Remember the World Series Celebration. How About the Guy Who Made the Last Out?
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The boyhood dream was so vivid that Michael Martinez can still remember it in rich detail: how he stood at the left side of the plate and delivered the winning hit in the seventh game of the World Series for the Cleveland Indians.

headline: Ford Was Unprepared for Investor Revolt and C.E.O. Change
text: Ford Motor’s many gaffes under Mark Fields were becoming an existential crisis for the $43 billion carmaker’s founding family. Two weeks ago, a majority of those shareholders not named Ford voted to abolish the family’s super-voting stock. The Fords got the message, and Mr. Fields, the chief executive, is now leaving. But naming a 62-year-old from the furniture trade to replace him hints at how unprepared the family was for a revolt.

headline: Review: Liam Scarlett’s ‘Symphonic Dances’ Celebrates a Ballerina
text: LONDON — A vast, cavernous space, dominated by a smoky cone of light. That’s the first image of Liam Scarlett’s new “Symphonic Dances,” an ambitious, large-scale work for the Royal Ballet that opened at the Royal Opera House here on May 18 and continues through Wednesday, sharing a program with William Forsythe’s “The Vertiginous Thrill of Exactitude,” Balanchine’s “Tarantella” and Christopher Wheeldon’s “Strapless.”

headline: Italienne
text: The chef Jared Sippel’s first New York restaurant is on its way to being something out of the ordinary.

headline: An Identity Crisis at Italienne
text: Jared Sippel might have had too much time to think before he opened Italienne. The restaurant, the chef’s first in New York City, has been open since the fall and is on its way to being something well out of the ordinary. But Mr. Sippel is trying to do so many things at once that his point of view gets garbled. The potential for confusion is even embedded in the name, which means Italian in French.

headline: N.B.A. Player Enes Kanter Blames Erdogan for Detention in Romania
text: Enes Kanter, the Turkish N.B.A. player who was detained in Romania over the weekend, spoke out against President Recep Tayyip Erdogan on Monday in New York and filled in some of the details of his odyssey.

headline: A New Reader Service: Ask the Sketch Guy Anything
text: I want to try something I’m calling “Ask the Sketch Guy.”

headline: Turkey Chides U.S. Envoy Over Handling of Brawl at Washington Protest
text: ISTANBUL — The Turkish Foreign Ministry summoned the American ambassador in Ankara on Monday to complain about the detention of two Turkish security officers outside the Turkish Embassy in Washington last week, a Turkish official said.

headline: Supreme Court Ruling Could Hinder ‘Patent Trolls’
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday placed tight limits on where patent lawsuits may be filed — a unanimous decision that was a blow to so-called patent trolls, or companies that buy patents not to use them but to demand royalties and sue for damages.

headline: Lawyers Are the Big Winners in the Inquiry Into the Election
text: The appointment of Robert S. Mueller III as special counsel to oversee the Justice Department’s investigation of possible Russian involvement in the 2016 election means that White House staff members and others connected to President Trump’s presidential campaign will need to do one thing quickly: Lawyer up.

headline: U.K. Conservatives Retreat After Backlash Over ‘Dementia Tax’
text: LONDON — Having called an early election in an attempt to expand her party’s majority in Parliament, Prime Minister Theresa May is pitching her “strong and stable leadership” at a time when Britain confronts the formidable challenge of leaving the European Union.

headline: Review: Before Pooh Bear, There Was Milne’s ‘The Lucky One’
text: Did someone declare this the Year to Dust Off Seldom Performed Plays About Feuding Brothers? First there was the Broadway revival of “The Price,” Arthur Miller’s 1968 drama, which closed on May 14. And now comes “The Lucky One,” the Mint Theater’s remounting of an A .A. Milne play written almost a century ago and given a brief run on Broadway in 1922.

headline: Big Game Hunter Killed by Elephant in Zimbabwe
text: A South African big game hunter was killed in Zimbabwe on Friday when an elephant that had been shot by another hunter fell on him.

headline: Trump’s Message in Saudi Arabia
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sharing Moroccan Shakshuka With Mourad Lahlou
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Shaved head glowing under the fluorescent kitchen lights, arms tattooed from shoulder to wrist, the chef Mourad Lahlou of Mourad restaurant waved a flower-patterned Japanese fan furiously over the countertop brazier, inciting the charcoal to glow.

headline: Michael Flynn Misled Pentagon About Russia Ties, Letter Says
text: WASHINGTON — Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s former national security adviser, misled Pentagon investigators about his income from companies in Russia and contacts with officials there when he applied for a renewal of his top-secret security clearance last year, according to a letter released Monday by the top Democrat on the House oversight committee.

headline: 59,000 Haitians Displaced by Earthquake Get Extra 6 Months in U.S.
text: MIAMI — More than seven years after an earthquake shattered Haiti’s capital, the secretary of Homeland Security, John F. Kelly, announced Monday that he would grant 58,700 Haitians another six months to live and work in the United States.

headline: Alexei Ratmansky Plans a New (Old) ‘Harlequinade’ for Ballet Theater
text: One of the 21st century’s greatest choreographers is taking another drink from the fount of classical ballet: Alexei Ratmansky plans to create a new “Harlequinade” next year for American Ballet Theater, a reconstruction of Marius Petipa’s ballet “Les Millions d’Arlequin.”

headline: These Baby Mice Were Born From Sperm That Went to Space
text: Litters of healthy mice — “space pups” — prove that mouse sperm can be freeze-dried, flown around on the International Space Station for nine months and then used to make babies, researchers from Japan are reporting in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

headline: Join Digital News Design at The New York Times
text: We are seeking technology-savvy interactive designers/editors to join our award-winning team in The New York Times newsroom.

headline: Interviewing Truck Drivers at a Crossroads
text: The sign said “Professional Drivers Only,” which was intimidating. At a truck stop in Effingham, Ill., gruff-looking figures wearing camo hats and hundred-mile stares sat at a counter of the Iron Skillet Restaurant.

headline: Homeless in New York

headline: Charles Ray Joins Ancient and Contemporary in Sculpture Debut in Rome
text: ROME — Mention the name of the American artist Charles Ray, and Italy holds its breath. Mr. Ray made waves in the country in 2013 when his “Boy with Frog,” a hypernaturalistic, 8-foot-tall sculpture commissioned by François Pinault, the French luxury goods magnate and collector, was removed from the Punta della Dogana in Venice because of protests on the part of locals, who demanded the return of a displaced lamppost there, a favorite smooching spot.

headline: Sending Addicts to Jail: Draconian and a Failure
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sea Lion Grabs a Girl Off a Dock, and Social Media Turns on Her Parents
text: Signs posted along the Steveston docks in Richmond, British Columbia, a popular tourist spot, do not mince words: Don’t feed the sea lions, because a bite “can cause very serious infections that may lead to amputation of a limb or even death.”

headline: Monica Lewinsky: Roger Ailes’s Dream Was My Nightmare
text: This is not another obituary for Roger Ailes, who died last week 10 months after being ousted at Fox News. It is, I hope, instead an obituary for the culture he purveyed — a culture that affected me profoundly and personally.

headline: Billy Bush, Former ‘Today’ Host, Plans Comeback After Lewd Trump Recording
text: Billy Bush, the former “Today” host whose lewd conversation with Donald J. Trump in 2005 roiled the presidential race, said in his first media interview since he left NBC in October that he spent his months away from the spotlight trying to “become a better, fuller man.”

text: Good morning.

headline: Fendi’s Gift to Rome: A Sculpture Shaped Like a Tree
text: PIETRASANTA, Italy — Shading his eyes from the warm Tuscan sun, the artist Giuseppe Penone watched as a crane hoisted a bronze tree trunk into position to cradle an 11-ton carved marble block.

headline: After Report on Killings of C.I.A. Sources, China Asserts Right to Defend Itself
text: The Chinese government has the obligation to defend its national security and the legal authority to protect China’s interests, a government spokeswoman said on Monday, the first official response to a New York Times report on the dismantling of C.I.A. espionage operations in China.

headline: Abandoning Human Rights in U.S. Foreign Policy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Drink Up, Business Travelers. The Minibar Is on the Way Out.
text: Do you think of hotel rooms as having spacious, old-school desks, the kind that invite long hours of working? And bureaus with a half-dozen drawers? Minibars, too? Well, perhaps you haven’t stayed at a hotel lately.

headline: Kenya’s Struggling Uber Drivers Fear a New Competitor: Uber
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — James Njoroge, an Uber driver in Nairobi, earns barely $5 at the end of a grueling 10-hour workday ferrying customers through snarled traffic across the Kenyan capital. Now a new competitor is in town, threatening to undercut even these meager earnings.

headline: A Global Health Scorecard Finds U.S. Lacking
text: Over the last 25 years, China, Ethiopia, the Maldive Islands, Peru, South Korea and Turkey had the greatest improvements in “deaths avoidable through health care at their economic level,” a complex but intriguing new measure of global mortality described last week in the Lancet.

headline: Cummings Urges Chaffetz to Subpoena Flynn
text: In a letter to Representative Jason Chaffetz, the chairman of the House Oversight Committee, Representative Elijah E. Cummings, the ranking minority member, requested a subpoena for documents related to any connections between Michael T. Flynn, the former national security adviser, and Russia. In the request, Mr. Cummings highlights an encounter between Mr. Flynn and high-level Russian officials that he failed to disclose for a security clearance check as reasoning for the subpoena.

headline: At Moogfest, Untamed Sounds and Futuristic Protests
text: DURHAM, N.C. — On Thursday afternoon at Moogfest, electronic sounds whooshed and crashed and videos of waveforms flickered and rippled behind Camae Ayewa, a musician, producer, poet, rapper and community organizer based in Philadelphia who records as Moor Mother. From her nest of equipment, she layered tumultuous beats and brittle electronic loops, and she declaimed ideas about history, racism, memory, technology and transformation. “Everyone is at home deleting the human parts of themselves/Control-Alt-Delete,” she intoned.

headline: A ‘Hamlet’ Poised Between Cultures (and Languages)
text: As if the poor guy weren’t conflicted enough, Hamlet has taken on an extra burden of ambivalence in the new Waterwell production of the play that bears his name. In addition to worrying about all the usual melancholy Dane stuff — whether to be or not to be, act or not to act, help or hurt his mom — he is now torn (to pieces) between cultural identities.

headline: ‘Twin Peaks’ Season 3, Episodes 1-2: Back in Style
text: Part of what made the first season of “Twin Peaks” so popular back in 1990 was that it filtered the director David Lynch’s surrealistic excesses through the more ordered mind of the TV veteran Mark Frost. After all the speculation and worry about what Showtime’s new version of the series would be, this week’s double-length opening salvo ended up balancing the disturbingly strange with the merely quirky and the somewhat normal, resulting — yet again — in something as surprisingly accessible as it is singularly bizarre. Two hours in, the third season is already perplexing, unsettling and potentially addicting.

headline: A New ‘Dirty Dancing,’ and Baby’s Love Story Is Just the Start
text: When “Dirty Dancing,” a coming-of-age film set in 1963 that depicts a family’s summer vacation spent at a Catskills resort, came out in 1987, it was an instant and unexpected sensation. Reportedly costing just $6 million, the movie earned $214 million at the box office and won the best original song Academy Award for “(I’ve Had) The Time of My Life.”

headline: The Patient Resilience of Iran’s Reformers
text: While President Trump basked in the flattery of Saudi Arabia’s absolute monarchy on Friday, about 75 percent of Iranian voters turned out to repudiate an authoritarian populist and re-elect their moderate president, Hassan Rouhani. Mr. Rouhani ran against extremism and on the promise of human rights, civil liberties, rational economic management and engagement with the world — a platform that won him 57 percent of the vote to his opponent’s 38.5 percent.

headline: Venice Biennale: Whose Reflection Do You See?
text: VENICE — Timing isn’t everything, but it’s a lot. If the bland, soft-power 2017 Venice Biennale, called “Viva Arte Viva,” had arrived two, or four, or six years ago, it might have passed muster, even made sense. But coming post-Brexit and post-Trump, it feels almost perversely out of sync with the political moment, and nowhere near strong enough to define a moment of its own.

headline: Ballet After Balanchine: 3 Choreographers Lead the Way
text: How do you get over George Balanchine? Supreme classicist, supreme modernist and still underrated as a superlative Romantic and dramatist, he remains ballet’s dominant figure.

headline: In ‘Grief Cottage,’ a Ghost and Other Things That Haunt Us
text: GRIEF COTTAGEBy Gail Godwin324 pages. Bloomsbury. $27.

headline: A Tiny Park Fights for Sunlight Among New York City Skyscrapers
text: New Yorkers have to elbow their way onto packed subways below ground. They have to eke out room on teeming sidewalks and streets just to get anywhere.

headline: G.I. Joe, It Turns Out, Had More Than One Father
text: G.I. Joe almost certainly had two fathers.

headline: Office of Government Ethics Declines Mulvaney’s Request to Suspend Ethics Inquiries
text: Walter M. Shaub, Jr., the director of the Office of Government Ethics, sent a letter on Monday to Mick Mulvaney, director of the Office of Management and Budget, declining a request to suspend its ethics inquiry into individual appointees and practices of agency ethics.

headline: Ariana Grande Manchester Concert Ends in Explosion, Panic and Death
text: MANCHESTER, England — An explosion that appeared to be a suicide bombing killed at least 22 people on Monday night and wounded 59 others at an Ariana Grande concert filled with adoring adolescent fans, in what the police were treating as a terrorist attack.

headline: Skipping French Open Is a Strategy That Fits Roger Federer
text: ROME — When John Isner received an invitation to play a charity exhibition match in Seattle in late April with Roger Federer, his initial reaction was to double-check the date.

headline: Hey Parents, Surprise, Fruit Juice Is Not Fruit
text: Many American children consume more than half of their fruit as juice, and the American Academy of Pediatrics has issued new guidelines clarifying its stance on that substitution: For most kids, it’s a bad thing.

headline: No ‘Fairy Godmother’ for the Subway: When $100 Billion Isn’t Enough
text: ALBANY — Nearly four decades ago, New York City’s subway system hit rock bottom: track fires, graffiti-covered cars and crime came to symbolize that era.

headline: At Cannes, the Glam and the Grim Mix Uneasily
text: CANNES, France — The Cannes Film Festival has always been a jarring clash of the glam and the grim, between often dark films and the stars who pose on the red carpet to promote them. This year, news and business developments were as much on the minds of festivalgoers as the movies and the paparazzi. Here are scenes from the first days of the festival:

headline: Unusual Place for a President’s Family on a Foreign Trip: Center Stage
text: JERUSALEM — At an Israeli children’s hospital, Melania Trump handed out blue canvas backpacks filled with Dr. Seuss books and emblazoned with a picture of the White House. At a forum in Saudi Arabia on combating extremism, Ivanka Trump stood in for her father when he got tired. And in Israel, Jared Kushner stuck by his father-in-law’s side as President Trump pushed for peace in the Middle East.

headline: Battle of Diller Island Goes Another Round, With a Pier 55 Appeal
text: Pier 55, the long-planned $200 million performing arts center on a new pier in the Hudson River, is not dead yet.

text: Gail Collins: Bret, it’s been a while since I had a chance to converse with a fellow Times columnist. Welcome! And in honor of your arrival, you get to choose our first subject.

headline: Zack Snyder to Step Away From ‘Justice League’ After Daughter’s Suicide
text: LOS ANGELES — Zack Snyder, the director behind the coming Warner Bros. movie “Justice League,” said on Monday that he would step away from the mega-budget superhero project to cope with the recent suicide of his daughter.

headline: U.N. Panel Releases Draft of Treaty to Ban Nuclear Arms
text: A United Nations disarmament panel presented the first draft on Monday of a proposed global treaty to ban nuclear weapons, which advocates called an important step that could hasten completion of a final text by early July.

headline: The Latest: Britain Raises Threat Level to Critical After Manchester Attack
text: ■ Prime Minister Theresa May announced on Tuesday night that Britain’s threat level had been raised to critical, its highest level, suggesting that another terrorist attack may be imminent.

headline: Trump’s Budget Cuts Deeply Into Medicaid and Anti-Poverty Efforts
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump plans to unveil on Tuesday a $4.1 trillion budget for 2018 that would cut deeply into programs for the poor, from health care and food stamps to student loans and disability payments, laying out an austere vision for reordering the nation’s priorities.

headline: Which Off Broadway Shows Did Obie Awards Like Best? ‘Oslo’ and ‘Underground Railroad Game’ Share Top Honors
text: An elegant big-cast production at Lincoln Center and an irreverent two-actor work at Ars Nova split a prize for best new American theater work at the annual Obie Awards on Monday night.

headline: Dina Merrill, Actress and Philanthropist, Dies at 93
text: Dina Merrill, the actress and heiress to two fortunes who wintered at her family’s Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach, Fla., as a child before becoming a leading lady in movies, most often in upper-class roles, died on Monday at her home in East Hampton, N.Y. She was 93.

headline: Trump’s First Budget Works Only if Wishes Come True
text: WASHINGTON — In its inaugural budget, the Trump administration projected that booming economic growth would allow the president to keep a wide range of expensive campaign promises while eliminating federal deficits in 10 years.

headline: Sessions Narrows Trump’s Order Against Sanctuary Cities
text: Attorney General Jeff Sessions on Monday clarified President Trump’s executive order on so-called sanctuary cities, narrowly defining such jurisdictions — and the money they could expect to receive from the federal government — in a way that appeared to fall far short of Mr. Trump’s previous threats to starve all federal funding from localities that limit their cooperation with federal immigration enforcement.

headline: Trump Budget Cuts Programs for Poor While Sparing Many Older People
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s spending blueprint seeks to balance the federal budget through unprecedented cuts to programs for poor and working-class families, effectively pitting them against older Americans who would largely escape the budget ax.

headline: Panic After Terrorist Bombing at Ariana Grande Concert
text: ISIS has claimed responsibility for the deadly explosion at an arena in Manchester, England, where the American pop singer Ariana Grande had been performing on Monday night.

headline: Robert H. Boyle, a Watchdog of the Hudson River, Dies at 88
text: Robert H. Boyle, a Brooklyn-born sportswriter and angler who became the unofficial guardian of the Hudson River as a crusading conservationist and a founder of a widely replicated watchdog group called Riverkeeper, died on Friday in Cooperstown, N.Y. He was 88.

headline: Figure Skating Event
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — One of the things I like about Zhouqin Burnikel’s puzzles is that, more often than not, she will find some oddity of the English language that typically goes unnoticed and point it out to us.

headline: More Evidence Points to North Korea in Ransomware Attack
text: SAN FRANCISCO — More evidence emerged Monday that North Korean hackers were behind the global ransomware attack that still holds hundreds of thousands of computers hostage.

headline: The Key Spending Cuts and Increases in Trump’s Budget
text: The White House released more details of its federal budget proposal on Monday. It includes substantial cuts to Medicaid and other aid to the poor. Because it comes packaged with tax cuts, it assumes the economy will grow faster as a result and ultimately balance the budget by 2027. It is, however, unlikely to pass Congress as is.

headline: A Yankees Win Follows a Duel, and a Review
text: The Yankees beat the Kansas City Royals, 4-2, on Monday at Yankee Stadium in a game that featured three Yankee home runs, one very good performance by a starting pitcher, and the unveiling of a new section of seats in right field designed to look like a courtroom in honor of a rookie slugger.

headline: ‘Better Call Saul’ Season 3, Episode 7 Recap: Jimmy Goes Backward
text: I’m starting to think that “Better Call Saul” is an extended and highly persuasive argument against a career in the law. Everything about the profession as it’s portrayed here is either dull, odious or cutthroat. The point of Kim’s outburst with Page in this episode is that Kim feels guilty about roughing up Chuck at that disbarment hearing. But did you recall what was said before and after this flare of temper?

text: SAN ANTONIO — The Golden State Warriors rolled past the San Antonio Spurs, 129-115, on Monday night to complete a dominant four-game sweep in the N.B.A.’s Western Conference finals.

text: As Britain continued to grieve on Friday after an attack earlier this week at an Ariana Grande show in Manchester, England, that killed 22 people, investigators pressed ahead with efforts to unravel the network that is believed to assisted the bomber, Salman Abedi.

text: SEATTLE — Today, most people know Amazon’s Echo speaker as an easy way to play music using voice commands, but the device and others like it are catching on as ways to control light switches, thermostats and other smart home appliances.

headline: Park Geun-hye, Ousted Leader of South Korea, Denies All Charges in Court
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Park Geun-hye, South Korea’s recently impeached and ousted president, made her first appearance in court on Tuesday, denying all criminal charges against her, as one of the biggest trials in the country’s history began.

headline: With the 2018 Olympics in South Korea, Will the North Be Participant or Provocateur?
text: As preparations accelerate for the 2018 Winter Olympics in South Korea, sporting relations on the divided Korean Peninsula in recent years have seldom appeared more amicable, despite the building nuclear tensions and escalating talk of war.

headline: Writers From the Right and Left React to Trump’s Riyadh Speech, and More
text: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. That’s why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.

headline: Barcelona Attack Adds to the Toll of Terrorism in Western Europe
